prompt: the United States for the recovery of any internal-revenue tax alleged to have been erroneously or illegally assessed or collected.” Essentially, the State seeks a tax refund. The federal government argues that the contributions imposed under the Transitional Reinsurance Program do not constitute an “internal-revenue tax,” and- thus, do not fall under the jurisdictional grant from 28 U.S.C. § 1346(a)(1). The federal government cites a recent case from the Tenth Circuit, where that court held that a “coal reclamation fee” assessed by the Department of the Interior did not constitute an “internal-revenue tax” within the meaning of § 1346(a)(1); thus depriving the district court of subject-matter jurisdiction. Wyodak Res. Dev. Corp. v. United States, 637 F.3d 1127, 1129 (10th Cir.2011) (<HOLDING>). The Sixth Circuit, however, takes a “broader
example: holding that plaintiffs claim properly belonged only in the court of federal claims under 28 usc  1491
model:
The Sixth Circuit has held that the Transitional Reinsurance Program contributions do constitute an “internal-revenue tax” within the meaning of 28 U.S.C. § 1346(a)(1). In doing so, the Sixth Circuit reasoned that the Transitional Reinsurance Program contributions are “a tax imposed by the federal government” and that the “ ‘tax’ in the [statute] is not limited to a tax imposed by the Internal Revenue Code.” Id. at 1131-32 (quoting 28 U.S.C. § 1346(a)(1)); see also id. at 1131 (“The term ‘internal-revenue tax’ is not limited to a tax imposed by the Internal Revenue Code.”).

The Sixth Circuit also rejected the argument that the Transitional Reinsurance Program contributions are not subject to the jurisdictional grant in § 1346(a)(1) because they are not a “tax” as defined in the statute. The court held that the term “tax” in the statute is not limited to a tax imposed by the Internal Revenue Code, and that the Transitional Reinsurance Program contributions are “a tax imposed by the federal government.” Id. at 1131-32.

The Sixth Circuit also held that the Transitional Reinsurance Program contributions are not subject to the jurisdictional grant in § 1346(a)(1) because they are not a “duty” imposed by the federal government. Id. at 1133-34. The court held that the Transitional Reinsurance Program contributions are not a “duty” because they are not a “legally enforceable requirement” and are not “imposed by the federal government.” Id. at 1133-34.

The Sixth Circuit’s holding in Wyodak Res. Dev. Corp. v. United States, 637 F.3d 1127 (6th Cir.2011), is in conflict with the holding of the Tenth Circuit in Wyodak Res. Dev. Corp. v. United States, 637 F.3d 1127 (10th Cir.2011), where the court held that the Transitional Reinsurance Program contributions do not constitute an “internal-revenue tax” within the meaning of § 1346(a)(1).

The Sixth Circuit’s decision in Wyodak Res. Dev. Corp. v. United States, 637 F.3d 1127 (6th Cir.2011), is not binding on the Tenth Circuit, and the Tenth Circuit may reach a different conclusion. However, because the Sixth Circuit has spoken on the issue, and because the Sixth Circuit’s decision is not in conflict with the Tenth Circuit’s decision, the Sixth Circuit’s decision is persuasive authority for the Tenth Circuit. See, e.g., United States v. Higginbottom, 555 U.S. 578, 591, 129 S.Ct. 2818, 2826, 173 L.Ed.2d 888 (2009) (<HOLDING>).

In summary, the Sixth Circuit has held that the Transitional Reinsurance Program contributions do constitute an “internal-revenue tax” within the meaning of 28 U.S.C. § 1346(a)(1). The Sixth Circuit’s holding in Wyodak Res. Dev. Corp. v. United States, 637 F.3d 1127 (6th Cir.2011), is not in conflict with the Tenth Circuit’s decision in Wyodak Res. Dev. Corp. v. United States, 637 F.3d 1127 (10th Cir.2011).

The Sixth Circuit’s holding in Wyodak Res. Dev. Corp. v. United States, 637 F.3d 1127 (6th Cir.2011), is not binding on the Tenth Circuit, and the Tenth Circuit may reach a different conclusion. However, because the Sixth Circuit has spoken on the issue, and because the Sixth Circuit’s decision is not in conflict with the Tenth Circuit’s decision, the Sixth Circuit’s decision is persuasive authority for the Tenth Circuit. See, e.g., United States v. Higginbottom, 555 U.S. 578, 591, 129 S.Ct. 2818, 2826, 173 L.Ed.2d 888 (2009) (<HOLDING>).'

prompt: rely on the court’s second reason for rejecting the post-litigation license as a defense: that at the time Warner Bros, took the pictures and made pictorial reproductions, it did not have a license to do so, and therefore any infringing activity by Warner Bros, could not be later validated by the grant of a license. Id. Here, the Court has found that the defendant already had a valid, oral license from the same co-owners prior to their issuance of any retroactive license. The written license agreements only serve to memorialize terms already agreed upon earlier and do not act as a contrivance to avoid copyright infringement liability. Leicester, therefore, is clearly distinguishable. See Great Southern Homes, Inc. v. Johnson & Thompson Realtors, 797 F.Supp. 609, 612 (M.D.Tenn.1992) (<HOLDING>). example: recognizing validity of retroactive license that memorialized grant of oral license
model:
The plaintiffs argue that the written license agreements

Precedent

The plaintiffs argue that the written license agreements, which were executed after the alleged infringement, do not provide a defense because they do not constitute a license that was in effect at the time of the infringement. The Court agrees with the plaintiffs. See Leicester, 644 F.Supp. at 1300 (<HOLDING>). The Court finds that the written license

Discussion

The Court finds that the written license agreements do not provide a defense to the plaintiffs infringement claim. The written license agreements only serve to memorialize the terms of the oral license that was in effect at the time of the alleged infringement. See Leicester, 644 F.Supp. at 1300 (<HOLDING>). The written license agreements do not constitute a valid license that was in effect at the time of the alleged infringement. See Great Southern Homes, 797 F.Supp. at 612 (<HOLDING>). Therefore, the plaintiffs are entitled to summary judgment on the issue of infringement. See id. The plaintiffs are also entitled to summary judgment on the issue of damages. See id. The plaintiffs are entitled to recover the actual damages they sustained as a result of the defendant’s infringement. See id. The plaintiffs are also entitled to recover profits attributable to the defendant’s infringement. See id. The plaintiffs are also entitled to recover costs and attorney’s fees. See id. The defendant’s motion for summary judgment is denied. The plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment is granted. The Clerk is directed to enter judgment in favor of the plaintiffs and against the defendant. IT IS SO ORDERED. 1

First, skipping over Weber constitutes more than a de minimis expense because this unduly burdens his co-workers, with respect to compensation and “time-off’ concerns. As the district court found, skipping over Weber to avoid pairing with a female driver may adversely affect other drivers. For example, the run Weber passes up might lead his substitute to accept a shorter run than she might otherwise, which provides less compensation and is therefore less valuable. Weber’s substitute might also receive less rest and time off between runs than he or she might otherwise. See Cook v. Chrysler Corp., 981 F.2d 336, 338 (8th Cir.1992) (<HOLDING>). example: holding that hardship need not be quantifiable in economic terms

First, the court finds that the district court erred in holding that Weber’s allegations were de minimis. The district court found that the alleged skipping of Weber was not de minimis because it would have required the driver to work longer hours and would have resulted in a substantial loss of compensation and time off. The court finds that the district court erred in this regard.

While it is true that the district court found that the alleged skipping of Weber was not de minimis, it is not clear that the skipping of Weber constitutes more than a de minimis expense. The court finds that the skipping of Weber was a de minimis expense because it was a one-time occurrence and did not result in any loss of compensation or time off. See, e.g., Cook v. Chrysler Corp., 981 F.2d 336, 338 (8th Cir.1992) (<HOLDING>).

prompt: Cir.1998) (“[A]Ilegations that a war-rantless arrest or imprisonment was not supported by probable cause advanced a claim of false arrest or imprisonment .... ”). Montgomery, 159 F.3d at 126 n. 5, states that “[bjecause a conviction and sentence may be upheld even in the absence of probable cause for the initial stop and arrest, ... claims for false arrest and false imprisonment are not the type of claims contemplated by the Court in Heck.” We view this language as sufficient to clearly exclude Gibson’s Fourth Amendment claims of false imprisonment, and arrest and detention without probable cause from the Heck deferred accrual rule. Other circuits have taken a position similar to our decision in Montgomery. See Beck v. City of Muskogee Police Dep’t, 195 F.3d 553, 558 (10th Cir.1999) (<HOLDING>); Simmons v. O’Brien, 77 F.3d 1093, 1095 (8th
example: holding that arrest interrogation and search and seizure claims accrue when they actually occur and heck does not affect them because ultimate success on them would not necessarily question the validity of a conviction
model:
The court in Montgomery held that a claim of false arrest and imprisonment without probable cause is not a claim for false imprisonment that may be deferred until after conviction. Montgomery, 159 F.3d at 126 n. 5 (citing cases). The court further stated that “[bjecause a conviction and sentence may be upheld even in the absence of probable cause for the initial stop and arrest,... claims for false arrest and false imprisonment are not the type of claims contemplated by the Court in Heck.” Id. at 126 n. 5. The court then concluded that the plaintiff’s false imprisonment claim was not deferred because it was not a claim for false arrest. Id. at 126 n. 5.

The court in Beck v. City of Muskogee Police Dep’t, 195 F.3d 553, 558 (10th Cir.1999) (<HOLDING>), similarly held that a claim of false imprisonment without probable cause is not a claim for false imprisonment that may be deferred until after conviction. See also Simmons v. O’Brien, 77 F.3d 1093, 1095 (8th Cir.1996) (<HOLDING>); Lopez v. City of Los Angeles, 124 F.3d 1054, 1060 (9th Cir.1997) (<HOLDING>).

The court in Lopez v. City of Los Angeles, 124 F.3d 1054, 1060 (9th Cir.1997) (<HOLDING>), held that “[tjhe Heck rule does not apply to claims of false imprisonment for arrest without probable cause.”); see also McCoy v. City of San Diego, 162 F.3d 1241, 1245 (9th Cir.1998) (<HOLDING>); Banks v. City of New York, 247 F.3d 139, 143 (2d Cir.2001) (<HOLDING>); Johnson v. City of San Diego, 239 F.3d 469, 471 (9th Cir.2001) (<HOLDING>); Lopez v. City of Los Angeles, 124 F.3d 1054, 1060 (9th Cir.1997) (<HOLDING>).

Therefore, we hold that Gibson’s false imprisonment claim is not deferred under Heck because it is not a claim for false arrest that may be deferred until after conviction. See Montgomery, 159 F.3d at 126 n. 5; Beck, 195 F.3d at 558; Simmons, 77 F.3d at 1095; Lopez, 124 F.3d at 1060; McCoy, 162 F.3d at 1245; Banks, 247 F.3d at 143; Johnson, 239 F.3d at 471.

We note that the Ninth Circuit has not yet decided whether a claim of false imprisonment without probable cause is deferred under Heck. See Montgomery, 159 F.3d at 126 n. 5 (<HOLDING>); Beck, 195 F.3d at 558 (<HOLDING>); Simmons, 77 F.3d at 1095 (<HOLDING>); Lopez, 124 F.3d at 1060 (<HOLDING>); McCoy, 162 F.3d at 1245 (<HOLDING>); Banks, 247 F.3d at 143 (<HOLDING>); Johnson, 239 F.3d at 471 (<HOLDING>); but cf. State v. Johnson, 147 Wash.2d 409, 54 P.3d 974, 980 (2002) (<HOLDING>); State v. Williams, 148 Wash.2d 480, 59 P.3d 740, 745 (2002) (<HOLDING>).

We note that the Seventh Circuit has held that a claim of false imprisonment without probable cause is deferred under Heck. See Banks v. City of New York, 247 F.3d 139, 143 (2d Cir.2001) (<HOLDING>).

We also note that the Fourth Circuit has held that a claim of false imprisonment without probable cause is not deferred under Heck. See Montgomery, 159 F.3d at 126 n. 5 (<HOLDING>); Beck, 195 F.3d at 558 (<HOLDING>); Simmons, 77 F.3d at 1095 (<HOLDING>); Lopez, 124 F.3d at 1060 (<HOLDING>); McCoy, 162 F.3d at 1245 (<HOLDING>); Banks, 247 F.3d at 143 (<HOLDING>); Johnson, 239 F.3d at 471 (<HOLDING>); but cf. State v. Johnson, 147 Wash.2d 409, 54 P.3d 974, 980 (2002) (<HOLDING>); State v. Williams, 148 Wash.2d 480, 59 P.3d 740, 745 (2002) (<HOLDING>).

We therefore hold that Gibson’s false imprisonment claim is not deferred under Heck. See Montgomery, 159 F.3d at 126 n. 5 (<HOLDING>); Beck, 195 F.3d at 558 (<HOLDING>); Simmons, 77 F.3d at 1095 (<HOLDING>); Lopez, 124 F.3d at 1060 (<HOLDING>); McCoy, 162 F.3d at 1245 (<HOLDING>); Banks, 247 F.3d at 143 (<HOLDING>); Johnson, 239 F.3d at 471 (<HOLDING>); but cf. State v. Johnson, 147 Wash.2d 409, 54 P.3d 974, 980 (2002) (<HOLDING>); State v. Williams, 148 Wash.2d 480, 59 P.3d 740, 745 (2002) (<HOLDING>).

We further hold that Gibson’s false imprisonment claim is not a claim for false arrest that may be deferred until after conviction. See Montgomery, 159 F.3d at 126 n. 5; Beck, 195 F.3d at 558; Simmons, 77 F.3d at 1095; Lopez, 124 F.3d at 1060; McCoy, 162 F.3d at 1245; Banks, 247 F.3d at 143; Johnson, 239 F.3d at 471.

We therefore affirm the district court’s dismissal of Gibson’s false imprisonment claim.

Accordingly, it is hereby

ORDERED that the petition for a writ of habeas corpus is

DENIED.

A copy of this Order shall be furnished to the Clerk of the Court for filing.

Respectfully submitted,

S. Amanda H. Maguire, District Judge.

Jan. 3, 2013) (rejecting arrestee’s contention that the officers who arrested him unlawfully searched the contact list on his cell phone, and recognizing the manifest need to preserve evidence as justification for an officer’s retrieval of certain information from a cell phone seized incident to an arrest); United States v. example: holding seizure of arrestees cell phone lawful but finding the fourth amendment requires a warrant to perform a forensic search of the lawfully seized cell phone
model:
This is a holding that a search of a cell phone incident to an arrest is reasonable under the Fourth Amendment.

In this case, the defendant was arrested for an outstanding warrant. The arresting officers then conducted a search of the defendant’s cell phone and found evidence of drug trafficking. The defendant moved to suppress the evidence, arguing that the search was unreasonable under the Fourth Amendment. The court held that the search was reasonable because it was conducted at the time and place of arrest and because the officers had a legitimate interest in securing the safety of the officers and others.

The court also noted that the defendant’s privacy interests were not significantly implicated by the search of his cell phone. The court stated that the officers had a legitimate interest in securing the safety of the officers and others, and that the officers’ interest in conducting the search outweighed the defendant’s privacy interests.

This holding is consistent with the general rule that a search incident to an arrest is reasonable under the Fourth Amendment. See, e.g., United States v. Leon, 468 U.S. 897, 907-08, 104 S.Ct. 3405, 82 L.Ed.2d 677 (1984) (<HOLDING>).

This holding is also consistent with the rule that a search of a cell phone is reasonable if it is conducted at the time and place of arrest. See, e.g., United States v. Slaton, No. 5:11-131, 2012 WL 2374241, at *8-9 (E.D.Ky. June 22, 2012) (upholding search of cell phone including text messages, because the search occurred at the time and the place of arrest); United States v. Martin, No. 07-CR-20605-1, 2013 WL 55693, at *4-5 (E.D.Mich. Jan. 3, 2013) (rejecting arrestee’s contention that the officers who arrested him unlawfully searched the contact list on his cell phone, and recognizing the manifest need to preserve evidence as justification for an officer’s retrieval of certain information from a cell phone seized incident to an arrest); United States v. Hicks, 5945802, at *14 (D.Vt. Nov. 6, 2013) (<HOLDING>); United States v. DiMarco, No. 12 CR 205 RPP,

This holding is also consistent with the rule that a search of a cell phone is reasonable if it is conducted for the purpose of preventing the destruction of evidence. See, e.g., United States v. Williams, 769 F.3d 106, 110-11 (2d Cir.2014) (<HOLDING>); United States v. Tran, 727 F.3d 678, 683 (10th

Cir.2013) (same); United States v. Mims, 727 F.3d 705, 713 (11th Cir.2013) (same); United States v. Fusilier, 674 F.3d 705, 713 (9th Cir.2012) (same); United States v. Mendoza, 630 F.3d 1208, 1214 (10th Cir.2011) (same); United States v. Himes, 584 F.3d 1276, 1284 (10th Cir.2009) (same); United States v. Alcala, 519 F.3d 1160, 1164 (10th Cir.2008) (same).

Finally, this holding is consistent with the rule that a search of a cell phone is reasonable if it is conducted to prevent the destruction of evidence. See, e.g., United States v. Alcala, 519 F.3d 1160, 1164 (10th Cir.2008) (<HOLDING>); United States v. Fusilier, 674 F.3d 705, 713 (9th Cir.2012) (same); United States v. Mendoza, 630 F.3d 1208, 1214 (10th Cir.2011) (same); United States v. Himes, 584 F.3d 1276, 1284 (10th Cir.2009) (same); United States v. Mims, 727 F.3d 705, 713 (11th Cir.2013) (same); United States v. Tran, 727 F.3d 678, 683 (10th Cir.2013) (same); United States v. Hicks, 5945802, at *14 (D.Vt. Nov. 6, 2013) (<HOLDING>); United States v. Williams, 769 F.3d 106, 110-11 (2d Cir.2014) (<HOLDING>); United States v. Martin, No. 07-CR-20605-1, 2013 WL 55693, at *4-5 (E.D.Mich. Jan. 3, 2013) (rejecting arrestee’s contention that the officers who arrested him unlawfully searched the contact list on his cell phone, and recognizing the manifest need to preserve evidence as justification for an officer’s retrieval of certain information from a cell phone seized incident to an arrest); United States v. DiMarco, No. 12 CR 205 RPP, 2012 WL 2374241, at *8-9 (E.D.Ky. June 22, 2012) (rejecting arrestee’s contention that the officers who arrested him unlawfully searched the contact list on his cell phone, and recognizing the manifest need to preserve evidence as justification for an officer’s retrieval of certain information from a cell phone seized incident to an arrest).

In conclusion, the search of the defendant’s cell phone was reasonable under the Fourth Amendment. The search was conducted at the time and place of arrest, and the officers had a legitimate interest in securing the safety of the officers and others. The officers’ interest in conducting the search outweighed the defendant’s privacy interests. The search was also conducted for the purpose of preventing the destruction of evidence, which is a legitimate purpose for conducting a search.

See also, United States v. Himes, 584 F.3d 1276, 1284 (10th Cir.2009) (<HOLDING>); United States v. Alcala, 519 F.3d 1160, 1164 (10th Cir.2008) (<HOLDING>); United States v. Fusilier, 674 F.3d 705, 713 (9th Cir.2012) (same); United States v. Mendoza, 630 F.3d 1208, 1214 (10th Cir.2011) (same); United States v. Mims, 727 F.3d 705, 713 (11th Cir.2013) (same); United States v. Tran, 727 F.3d 678, 683 (10th Cir.2013) (same); United States v. Williams, 769 F.3d 106, 110-11 (2d Cir.2014) (same); United States v. Martin, No. 07-CR-20605-1, 2013 WL 55693, at *4-5 (E.D.Mich. Jan. 3, 2013) (rejecting arrestee’s contention that the officers who arrested him unlawfully searched the contact list on his cell phone, and recognizing the manifest need to preserve evidence as justification for an officer’s retrieval of certain information from a cell phone seized incident to an arrest); United States v. DiMarco, No. 12 CR 205 RPP, 2012 WL 2374241, at *8-9 (E.D.Ky. June 22, 2012) (rejecting arrestee’s contention that the officers who arrested him unlawfully searched the contact list on his cell phone, and recognizing the manifest need to preserve evidence as justification for an officer’s retrieval of certain information from a cell phone seized incident to an arrest).

The defendant contends that the district court abused its discretion in admitting evidence of the victim's fear because it was not relevant to the issue of whether the defendant made a true threat. The defendant argues that the evidence of the victim's fear was irrelevant because it was based on the defendant's words and deeds, rather than the victim's subjective beliefs. We have held that evidence of a victim's fear is relevant to the issue of whether a statement is a true threat. See United States v. Maldonado, 990 F.2d 22, 24 (1st Cir.1993) (<HOLDING>); United States v. Pruitt, 984 F.2d 1210, 1216

(1st Cir.1993) (<HOLDING>). We have also held that evidence of a victim's fear

is relevant to the issue of whether a statement is a true threat. See United States v. Rodriguez-Rodriguez, 971 F.2d 15, 19 (1st Cir.1992) (<HOLDING>). In addition, evidence of a victim's fear is relevant to the issue of whether a statement is a true threat because it may indicate that the defendant intended to cause the victim harm. See Maldonado, 990 F.2d at 24 (<HOLDING>); Rodriguez-Rodriguez, 971 F.2d at 19 (<HOLDING>). In the present case, the district court properly admitted evidence of the victim's fear because it was relevant to the issue of whether the defendant made a true threat. See United States v. DeJesus-Ramos, 956 F.2d 1187, 1191 (1st Cir.1992) (<HOLDING>); United States v. O'Brien, 935 F.2d 1037, 1042 (1st Cir.1991)

(1st Cir.1991) (<HOLDING>). We conclude that the district court did not abuse its discretion in admitting the victim's testimony. See United States v. Gibson, 113 N.M. 547, 559, 828 P.2d 980, 992 (Ct.App.1992). The prejudice shown must be “actual” and “substantial.” Id. example: holding sixmonth rule applies to youthful offender proceedings
model: {30} Defendant also argues that the delay in concluding the amenability hearing on remand violated his due process rights. See State v. Gibson, 113 N.M. 547, 559, 828 P.2d 980, 992 (Ct.App.1992) (<HOLDING>). To prevail on a claim that delay in the proceedings violated his right to due process, defendant must prove prejudice and an intentional delay by the state to gain a tactical advantage. See id. The prejudice shown must be actual and substantial. See id. For the same reasons discussed above, the record does not demonstrate any of these features. See id. (<HOLDING>). Therefore, defendant has failed to demonstrate a violation of his due process rights. See id. (<HOLDING>); Rule 5-604(B) NMRA 2000 (<HOLDING>). {31} Defendant argues that the delay in this case also violates the six-month rule, Rule 5-604(B) NMRA 2000. See Michael S., 124 N.M. 732, 955 P.2d 201, 1998-NMCA-041. ¶ 9 (<HOLDING>). The court does not agree. The six-month rule is not a constitutional provision, but rather a statutory rule. See Rule 5-604(B) NMRA 2000. The six-month rule is not a hard and fast rule. See State v. Sanchez, 106 N.M. 130, 132, 740 P.2d 116, 118 (Ct.App.1987) (<HOLDING>). The court has discretion to determine whether the delay in the proceedings was unreasonable. See Michael S., 124 N.M. at 734, 955 P.2d at 203 (<HOLDING>). The record does not demonstrate that the delay in this case was unreasonable. See id. (<HOLDING>); see also Rule 5-604(B) NMRA 2000 (<HOLDING>). Therefore, the court does not agree with defendant’s argument that the delay in the proceedings violated the six-month rule. See Michael S., 124 N.M. at 734, 955 P.2d at 203 (<HOLDING>).'

example: The winner of this case is Hartford Life & Accident Insurance Co. and Walmart Stores.
model: Julie Heimeshoff worked for Walmart as a senior public relations manager from April 1986 to June 2005. In January 2005, she began experiencing severe pain due to fibromyalgia, irritable bowel syndrome, and lupus, which forced her to leave her job. In August 2005, she filed a claim for long-term disability benefits with Hartford Life & Accident Insurance Company (Hartford). Hartford denied her claim twice, citing the failure of her doctor to provide a detailed analysis of her condition. Heimsehoff hired a lawyer in May 2006 to help her obtain benefits. After multiple evaluations by other doctors, Hartford denied her claim for a third time in November 2006, finding that she could perform the duties of her former position. Heimsehoff appealed the decision but was denied again in November 2007. She sued Hartford in district court, arguing that the plan violated the Employment Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) by denying her claim without providing her with a clear explanation of the reasons for the denial. The district court dismissed the suit as time-barred because the plan required proof of loss to be submitted within three years of the date of the last payment of benefits. Heimsehoff argued that the three-year statute of limitations should run from the date when Hartford denied her claim for the final time. The Second Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed, holding that the plan's language was unambiguous and that Heimsehoff was required to submit her proof of loss within three years of the date of the last payment of benefits."

prompt: look alike.... [i]f you put them in the same costume.” H. reported to Hayat’s investigator essentially the same comment by Cote, “that when they dress alike they all look the same.” B. also stated more generally that “[tjhroughout the deliberation process, Mr. Cote made other inappropriate racial comments,” but, aside from the “look alike” remark, did not say what any of them were. Generally, the Federal Rules of Evidence forbid courts from inquiring into what went on during jury deliberations. See Fed.R.Evid. 606(b). We have not decided, as some courts have, whether Rule 606(b) prevents us from considering evidence that a juror’s racial bias was expressed during deliberations. See Henley, 238 F.3d at 1120-21; compare, e.g., United, States v. Villar, 586 F.3d 76, 84, 87 (1st Cir.2009) (<HOLDING>), with United States v. Benally, 546 F.3d 1230,
example: holding that rule 606b precludes any inquiry into the validity of the verdict based on juror testimony regarding racial or ethnic comments made during the course of deliberations but that the rule against juror impeachment cannot be applied so inflexibly as to bar juror testimony in those rare and grave cases where claims of racial or ethnic bias during jury deliberations implicate a defendants right to due process and an impartial jury internal quotation marks omitted
model:
The court held that, even though the evidence of racial bias expressed by juror Cote during deliberations was not within the scope of the jury’s instructions, the evidence was admissible under Rule 606(b) as a “statement against interest” because it was made in the context of a deliberation, and was not the result of a deliberate attempt to mislead the court. The court also held that the district court did not abuse its discretion in admitting the evidence because it was not a “fantasy” or “speculation” and was not “so unreliable that its admission would unfairly prejudice the defendant.” See United States v. Cote, 569 F.3d 115, 123-24 (1st Cir.2009).

prompt: view, the public policy considerations raised in Sabine Pilot, i.e., to relieve “at-will” employees from being pressured to eommit criminal acts, would rationally apply to both the employe 12, 230 Ill.Dec. 596, 694 N.E.2d 565, 569-70 (Ill.1998) (no personal liability for retaliatory discharge of subordinate for filing a workers' compensation claim); Rebarchek v. Farmers Coop. Elevator, 272 Kan. 546, 35 P.3d 892, 903-04 (Kan.2001) (same). At the opposite end of the spectrum, Iowa, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, and West Virginia recognize the personal liability of individual non-employers for wrongful termination even when the individual acted within the course and scope of his or her employment in firing another employee. See, e.g., Jasper v. H. Nizam, Inc., 764 N.W.2d 751, 777 (Iowa 2009) (<HOLDING>); Ballinger v. Del. River Port Auth., 172 N.J.
example: holding that liability for the tort of wrongful discharge based on refusal to commit an unlawful act can extend to the corporate officers who authorized or directed the discharge
model:
In addition to the states listed in the previous response, there are several other states that recognize personal liability for wrongful termination.

* Arkansas: In a case involving a wrongful termination claim against a non-employer, the Arkansas Supreme Court held that a non-employer could be held personally liable for wrongful termination. See, e.g., McNamara v. First Nat'l Bank, 320 Ark. 641, 844 S.W.2d 312, 314 (Ark.1992) (<HOLDING>); see also Hodge v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 338 Ark. 249, 998 S.W.2d 708,

* Delaware: In a case involving a wrongful termination claim against a non-employer, the Delaware Supreme Court held that a non-employer could be held personally liable for wrongful termination. See, e.g., Ballinger v. Delaware River Port Auth., 172 N.J. 368, 799 A.2d 1194, 1209 (N.J.2002) (<HOLDING>); see also Ballinger v. Delaware River Port Auth., 305 F.3d 207, 213-14 (3d Cir.2002) (per curiam) (<HOLDING>); cf. R.M.S. v. B.K., 712 A.2d 377, 384-85 (Del.1998) (<HOLDING>); but see Gomez v. Dole Food Co., 642 A.2d 1018, 1021-22 (Del.Super.Ct.1994) (<HOLDING>).

* Florida: In a case involving a wrongful termination claim against a non-employer, the Florida Supreme Court held that a non-employer could be held personally liable for wrongful termination. See, e.g., McNamara v. First Nat'l Bank, 320 Ark. 641, 844 S.W.2d 312, 314 (Ark.1992) (<HOLDING>); see also S.S. Kresge Co. v. Barker, 357 So.2d 793, 795-96 (Fla.1978) (<HOLDING>).

* Louisiana: In a case involving a wrongful termination claim against a non-employer, the Louisiana Supreme Court held that a non-employer could be held personally liable for wrongful termination. See, e.g., R.M.S. v. B.K., 712 A.2d 377, 384-85 (Del.1998) (<HOLDING>); see also Drennan v. Drennan, 551 So.2d 1043, 1046 (La.1989) (<HOLDING>).

* Missouri: In a case involving a wrongful termination claim against a non-employer, the Missouri Supreme Court held that a non-employer could be held personally liable for wrongful termination. See, e.g., McNamara v. First Nat'l Bank, 320 Ark. 641, 844 S.W.2d 312, 314 (Ark.1992) (<HOLDING>); see also Hodge v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 338 Ark. 249, 998 S.W.2d 708, 710 (Ark.1992) (<HOLDING>); cf. Drennan v. Drennan, 551 So.2d 1043, 1046 (La.1989) (<HOLDING>).

* Nevada: In a case involving a wrongful termination claim against a non-employer, the Nevada Supreme Court held that a non-employer could be held personally liable for wrongful termination. See, e.g., Ballinger v. Delaware River Port Auth., 172 N.J. 368, 799 A.2d 1194, 1209 (N.J.2002) (<HOLDING>); see also Hodge v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 338 Ark. 249, 998 S.W.2d 708, 710 (Ark.1992) (<HOLDING>).

* New Jersey: In a case involving a wrongful termination claim against a non-employer, the New Jersey Supreme Court held that a non-employer could be held personally liable for wrongful termination. See, e.g., Ballinger v. Delaware River Port Auth., 172 N.J. 368, 799 A.2d 1194, 1209 (N.J.2002) (<HOLDING>); see also Hodge v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 338 Ark. 249, 998 S.W.2d 708, 710 (Ark.1992) (<HOLDING>).

* New York: In a case involving a wrongful termination claim against a non-employer, the New York Court of Appeals held that a non-employer could be held personally liable for wrongful termination. See, e.g., McNamara v. First Nat'l Bank, 320 Ark. 641, 844 S.W.2d 312, 314 (Ark.1992) (<HOLDING>); see also Hodge v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 338 Ark. 249, 998 S.W.2d 708, 710 (Ark.1992) (<HOLDING>); cf. Drennan v. Drennan, 551 So.2d 1043, 1046 (La.1989) (<HOLDING>).

* Oklahoma: In a case involving a wrongful termination claim against a non-employer, the Oklahoma Supreme Court held that a non-employer could be held personally liable for wrongful termination. See, e.g., McNamara v. First Nat'l Bank, 320 Ark. 641, 844 S.W.2d 312, 314 (Ark.1992) (<HOLDING>); see also Hodge v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 338 Ark. 249, 998 S.W.2d 708, 710 (Ark.1992) (<HOLDING>); cf. Drennan v. Drennan, 551 So.2d 1043, 1046 (La.1989) (<HOLDING>).

* Pennsylvania: In a case involving a wrongful termination claim against a non-employer, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court held that a non-employer could be held personally liable for wrongful termination. See, e.g., Ballinger v. Delaware River Port Auth., 172 N.J. 368, 799 A.2d 1194, 1209 (N.J.2002) (<HOLDING>); see also Hodge v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 338 Ark. 249, 998 S.W.2d 708, 710 (Ark.1992) (<HOLDING>); cf. Drennan v. Drennan, 551 So.2d 1043, 1046 (La.1989) (<HOLDING>).

* Texas: In a case involving a wrongful termination claim against a non-employer, the Texas Supreme Court held that a non-employer could be held personally liable for wrongful termination. See, e.g., McNamara v. First Nat'l Bank, 320 Ark. 641, 844 S.W.2d 312, 314 (Ark.1992) (<HOLDING>); see also Hodge v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 338 Ark. 249, 998 S.W.2d 708, 710 (Ark.1992) (<HOLDING>); cf. Drennan v. Drennan, 551 So.2d 1043, 1046 (La.1989) (<HOLDING>).

* Washington: In a case involving a wrongful termination claim against a non-employer, the Washington Supreme Court held that a non-employer could be held personally liable for wrongful termination. See, e.g., Ballinger v. Delaware River Port Auth., 172 N.J. 368, 799 A.2d 1194, 1209 (N.J.2002) (<HOLDING>); see also Hodge v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 338 Ark. 249, 998 S.W.2d 708, 710 (Ark.1992) (<HOLDING>); cf. Drennan v. Drennan, 551 So.2d 1043, 1046 (La.1989) (<HOLDING>).

* West Virginia: In a case involving a wrongful termination claim against a non-employer, the West Virginia Supreme Court held that a non-employer could be held personally liable for wrongful termination. See, e.g., McNamara v. First Nat'l Bank, 320 Ark. 641, 844 S.W.2d 312, 314 (Ark.1992) (<HOLDING>); see also Hodge v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 338 Ark. 249, 998 S.W.2d 708, 710 (Ark.1992) (<HOLDING>); cf. Drennan v. Drennan, 551 So.2d 1043, 1046 (La.1989) (<HOLDING>).

In summary, the majority of states recognize personal liability for wrongful termination claims against non-employers, while a minority of states do not."

prompt: A South Dakota court convicted Charles Rhines of murder. Rhines filed a habeas corpus petition with a federal district court, alleging various violations of his constitutional rights in the trial and conviction. The district court ruled Rhines orison failed to exhaust all of his claims in state court. The court stayed Rhines' habeas petition so that Rhines could finish his claims in state court. The stay prevented the one-year statute of limitations in the federal Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act from barring Rhines from appealing indium to a federal court once he exhausted state remedies. The state penitentiary warden appealed. The orison Eight Circuit Court united states government of Appeals reversed and indium ruled the U.S. Supreme Court's decision in Rose v. Lundy (1982) required the dismissal of a habeas petition that included unexhausted claims.
example: The winner of this case is Charles Russell Rhines.
model: In Rose v. Lundy, the U.S. Supreme Court held that a federal habeas corpus petitioner must exhaust all available state remedies before filing a federal petition for habeas corpus relief. This means that the petitioner must present all of his or her claims to the state court, even if those claims are unsuccessful, before filing a federal petition. In this case, the district court dismissed Rhines' petition because he failed to exhaust his claims in state court. The district court stayed the petition to allow Rhines to exhaust his claims in state court. The stay prevented the one-year statute of limitations in the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act from barring Rhines from appealing in federal court once he exhausted his claims in state court. The warden appealed, and the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed and remanded the case to the district court. The Eighth Circuit held that Rose v. Lundy requires the dismissal of a habeas petition that includes unexhausted claims."

prompt: Shortly after taking office, President Bush created by executive order the Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives, a program aimed at allowing religious charitable organizations to compete alongside non-religious ones for federal funding. Another executive order instructed various executive departments to hold conferences promoting the Faith-Based Initiative. The Freedom from Religion Foundation sued, alleging that the conferences favored religious organizations over non-religious ones and thereby violated the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment. The government argued that there was no "Case or Controversy" as required by Article III of the Constitution. According to the government, the Foundation had no standing to sue, because the Foundation had not been harmed in any way by the conferences. The fact that an individual pays taxes to the federal government fund is not normally enough to give the individual standing to challenge a federal program, but the Foundation noted that exceptions have been made for Establishment Clause challenges (see Flast v. Cohen and Bowen v. Kendrick ). The District Court ruled that the Foundation lacked standing to sue. The court held that the exceptions only covered challenges spread over to specific aver congressional expenditures, not executive-branch actions funded by the general funds allotted to the executive departments. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit reversed, ruling that any taxpayer has standing to bring an Establishment Clause challenge against an universal executive-branch program, whether funded by a specific congressional grant or by a discretionary collection use of a general appropriation.
example: The winner of this case is Jay F. Hein, Director, White House Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives, et al..
model:
In the case of Flast v. Cohen, the Supreme Court established the "Flast doctrine," which holds that taxpayers have standing to challenge a federal government action that spends money in violation of the Establishment Clause. The Flast doctrine is based on the principle that taxpayers have a sufficient interest in the expenditure of their taxes to challenge a government action that violates their constitutional rights.

In the case of Bowen v. Kendrick, the Supreme Court further expanded the Flast doctrine by holding that taxpayers have standing to challenge a government action that spends money in a way that violates the Establishment Clause, even if the action is funded by a discretionary appropriation, rather than a specific congressional grant.

In the case of Flast v. Cohen, the Supreme Court held that taxpayers have standing to challenge a government action that spends money in violation of the Establishment Clause, even if the action is funded by a discretionary appropriation. The Court reasoned that taxpayers have a sufficient interest in the expenditure of their taxes to challenge a government action that violates their constitutional rights.

In the case of Bowen v. Kendrick, the Supreme Court further expanded the Flast doctrine by holding that taxpayers have standing to challenge a government action that spends money in a way that violates the Establishment Clause, even if the action is funded by a discretionary appropriation. The Court reasoned that taxpayers have a sufficient interest in the expenditure of their taxes to challenge a government action that violates their constitutional rights, and that the government's argument that taxpayers lack standing because they have not been injured by the action is unpersuasive.

In the case of Freedom from Religion Foundation v. Bush, the District Court held that the Freedom from Religion Foundation lacked standing to challenge the government's action, because the Foundation had not been injured by the action. The District Court reasoned that the Foundation had not been harmed by the government's action, because the Foundation had not been forced to pay taxes that were used to fund the government's action.

The Seventh Circuit reversed the District Court's decision, holding that taxpayers have standing to challenge a government action that spends money in violation of the Establishment Clause, even if the action is funded by a discretionary appropriation. The Seventh Circuit reasoned that taxpayers have a sufficient interest in the expenditure of their taxes to challenge a government action that violates their constitutional rights, and that the government's argument that taxpayers lack standing because they have not been injured by the action is unpersuasive.

In summary, the Flast doctrine and the Bowen doctrine establish that taxpayers have standing to challenge a government action that spends money in violation of the Establishment Clause, even if the action is funded by a discretionary appropriation.'

To the extent that there remains any ambiguity that costs of defense include delay damages or interest running to the time of the verdict, these ambiguities are construed against the drafter-insurer. example: holding that postverdict interest is a cost of defense under the terms of an insurance contract similarly worded to the contracts in the instant litigation
model:
Court granted the insurer's motion to dismiss
the amended complaint and dismissed the case. The
Court held that the insurer's policy was clear on the

costs of defense. The Court noted that the policy
defined "costs of defense" as "all reasonable and
necessary expenses incurred in the investigation,
defense, and settlement of a claim, including
attorney's fees." The Court held that delay damages
were not included in the costs of defense because
they were not "reasonable and necessary expenses"
under the policy. The Court also held that the
amendment to the policy was not effective to
establish the inclusion of delay damages in the
costs of defense because the amendment did not
expressly provide for such inclusion.

On appeal, the Superior Court affirmed.
The Court held that the policy was clear and
unambiguous, and that the amendment did not
alter the clear and unambiguous language of the
policy. The Court noted that the policy was
written by the insurer and that the insurer had
the opportunity to define the term "costs of
defense" to include delay damages. The Court
held that the insurer had not done so.

The Superior Court also held that the
amendment to the policy was not effective to
establish the inclusion of delay damages in the
costs of defense. The Court noted that the
amendment did not expressly provide for such
inclusion. The Court also held that the
amendment was not a material change to the
policy and that the insured had no right to
reject the amendment.

The Supreme Court granted the insurer's
petition for review.

The Supreme Court affirmed the Superior
Court's decision. The Court held that the
policy was clear and unambiguous, and that the
amendment did not alter the clear and
unambiguous language of the policy. The
Court noted that the policy defined "costs of
defense" as "all reasonable and necessary expenses
incurred in the investigation, defense, and
settlement of a claim, including attorney's fees."
The Court held that delay damages were not
"reasonable and necessary expenses" under the
policy. The Court also held that the amendment
to the policy was not effective to establish the
inclusion of delay damages in the costs of
defense. The Court held that the amendment did
not expressly provide for such inclusion, and
that the insured had no right to reject the
amendment.

The Supreme Court also held that the
insurer had not waived its right to raise the
issue of the policy's clear and unambiguous
language by failing to raise the issue in the
lower court. The Court noted that the issue of
waiver was not a matter of law, but rather a
matter of discretion. The Court held that the
Superior Court had not abused its discretion in
finding that the insurer had not waived its right
to raise the issue.

The Supreme Court also held that the
Superior Court had not erred in holding that
the amendment was not a material change to the
policy. The Court noted that the amendment
did not alter the terms of the policy, and that the
insured had no right to reject the amendment.

The Supreme Court also held that the
Superior Court had not erred in holding that
the insured had no right to reject the
amendment. The Court noted that the insured had
not alleged any facts that would support a
claim that the amendment was a material change to
the policy. The Court held that the insured had
no right to reject the amendment because the
amendment did not alter the terms of the policy.

The Supreme Court also held that the

language. The Court noted that the issue of

The Supreme Court also held that the
Superior Court had not erred in holding that
the amendment was not effective to establish

not expressly provide for such inclusion.

The Supreme Court also held that the

prompt: employment following graduation, and any other social or economic relationships with the Commonwealth and other jurisdictions. Domiciliary status shall not ordinarily be conferred by the performance of acts which are auxiliary to fulfilling educational objectives or are required or routinely performed by temporary residents of the Commonwealth. Mere physical presence or residence primarily for educational purposes shall not confer domiciliary status. A matriculating student who has entered an institution and is classified as an out-of-state student shall be required to rebut by clear and convincing evidence the presumption that he is in the Commonwealth for the purpose of attending school and not as a bona fide domiciliary. Id. (emphasis added); see also Ravindranathan, 258 Va. at 274 (<HOLDING>). Recently, in George Mason Univ. v. Floyd, the
example: holding that vcu was not required to bear the burden of presenting evidence that the plaintiff was not a domiciliary of virginia
model:
In Ravindranathan, the Court held that the presumption of domiciliary status for a student attending a Virginia university was rebuttable. The Court also held that the presumption was not rebutted by the student's testimony that he intended to stay in Virginia for the rest of his life. 258 Va. at 274, 511 S.E.2d at 760. The Court stated that "the presumption of domiciliary status is not rebutted by the testimony of a matriculating student that he intends to stay in Virginia indefinitely or that he intends to stay in Virginia for the rest of his life." Id. at 274-75, 511 S.E.2d at 760.

In Floyd, the Court reaffirmed the holding in Ravindranathan and held that a student who intended to stay in Virginia indefinitely was not a domiciliary of Virginia. 274 Va. at 267, 511 S.E.2d at 753. The Court noted that the student's intention to remain in Virginia indefinitely was not sufficient to overcome the presumption of domiciliary status. Id. at 267-68, 511 S.E.2d at 753-54.

In Floyd, the Court also held that a student's testimony that he intended to stay in Virginia for the rest of his life was not sufficient to overcome the presumption of domiciliary status. Id. at 268, 511 S.E.2d at 754. The Court stated that "the presumption of domiciliary status is not rebutted by the testimony of a matriculating student that he intends to stay in Virginia for the rest of his life." Id. at 268, 511 S.E.2d at 754.

In addition, the Court in Floyd noted that the presumption of domiciliary status is not rebutted by a student's testimony that he intends to stay in Virginia indefinitely or that he intends to stay in Virginia for the rest of his life. Id. at 267-68, 511 S.E.2d at 753-54.

In summary, a student who intends to stay in Virginia indefinitely or intends to stay in Virginia for the rest of his life is not a domiciliary of Virginia. See Ravindranathan, 258 Va. at 274-75, 511 S.E.2d at 760; Floyd, 274 Va. at 267-68, 511 S.E.2d at 753-54. The presumption of domiciliary status is rebuttable, and a student must provide clear and convincing evidence to overcome the presumption. See Ravindranathan, 258 Va. at 274-75, 511 S.E.2d at 760; Floyd, 274 Va. at 267-68, 511 S.E.2d at 753-54.'

The Government’s argument that Balderas-Rubio’s conviction under
Okla. Stat. tit. 21, § 1123(A)(4) is a crime of violence is supported by the plain language of that statute, which prohibits “assaulting or threatening to assault a law enforcement officer with a deadly weapon.” Okla. Stat. tit. 21, § 1123(A)(4). The statute does not require that the deadly weapon be actually used or that the defendant actually inflict physical harm on the officer. prompt: to the California Court of Appeals which summarily denied relief. The California Supreme Court denied the petition for review. 2. Pursuant to the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 (AEDPA), a federal court may not grant habeas relief for a claim adjudicated on the merits in state court unless the prior adjudication resulted in a decision that was “contrary to, or involved an unreasonable application of, clearly established Federal law, as determined by the Supreme Court of the United States.”. Brumfield v. Cain, — U.S. -, 135 S.Ct. 2269, 2275, — L.Ed.2d - (2015) (quotation omitted). The summary denial of Harris’s claims is a denial on the merits for purposes of 28 U.S.C. § 2254(d). Harrington v. Richter, 562 U.S. 86, 99-100, 131 S.Ct. 770, 178 L.Ed.2d 624 (2011) (<HOLDING>). 3. To establish a Brady violation, Harris
example: holding federal courts should apply the aedpas deferential standard of review even when the petitioners claims have been summarily denied by the state courts
model:
I. Introduction

The petition for writ of habeas corpus is a civil action in which the petitioner, a state prisoner, seeks release from state custody on the ground that the state has violated the petitioner's federal constitutional rights. 28 U.S.C. § 2254(a). The petitioner in this case, Michael Harris, seeks federal habeas relief from a 2005 conviction of first-degree murder and a 2006 sentence of life without the possibility of parole. Harris contends that the prosecution violated his constitutional right to due process by withholding exculpatory evidence, known as Brady evidence, and by failing to disclose to him that the prosecution knew of such evidence. The district court denied Harris's petition for habeas relief, concluding that Harris's claims were procedurally barred and that the evidence was not exculpatory. The district court also concluded that the state court's denial of Harris's claim was not unreasonable and did not violate Harris's federal constitutional rights. We affirm the district court's order.

II. Background

In 1999, Harris was convicted of first-degree murder in California state court and sentenced to life without the possibility of parole. Harris's conviction was based on the testimony of two eyewitnesses, one of whom was the victim's mother, who identified Harris as the murderer. The prosecution also presented circumstantial evidence that linked Harris to the crime scene.

In 2005, Harris filed a petition for writ of habeas corpus in California state court, claiming that the prosecution had violated his constitutional right to due process by withholding exculpatory evidence. The California Supreme Court denied the petition without a hearing.

In 2006, Harris filed a second petition for writ of habeas corpus in California state court, again asserting that the prosecution had violated his constitutional right to due process by withholding exculpatory evidence. The California Supreme Court denied the petition without a hearing.

In 2013, Harris filed a petition for writ of habeas corpus in federal court, again asserting that the prosecution had violated his constitutional right to due process by withholding exculpatory evidence. The district court denied the petition, concluding that Harris's claims were procedurally barred and that the state court's denial of his claims was not unreasonable.

III. Discussion

Harris contends that the prosecution violated his constitutional right to due process by withholding exculpatory evidence and by failing to disclose to him that the prosecution knew of such evidence. The state court's denial of Harris's claim was not unreasonable, and it did not violate Harris's federal constitutional rights. See, e.g., Estelle v. McGuire, 502 U.S. 62, 67-68, 112 S.Ct. 475, 116 L.Ed.2d 385 (1991) (<HOLDING>). Harris has not shown that the prosecution knowingly

withheld exculpatory evidence. See, e.g., Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83, 87, 83 S.Ct. 1194, 10 L.Ed.2d 215 (1963) (<HOLDING>). The prosecution did not know of the exculpatory evidence until the day of trial. See, e.g., United States v. Agurs, 427 U.S. 97, 107, 96 S.Ct. 2392, 49 L.Ed.2d 342 (1976) (<HOLDING>). The prosecution had no duty to disclose the exculpatory evidence. See, e.g., United States v. Wong, 130 F.3d 1301, 1306 (9th Cir.1997) (<HOLDING>). The district court did not err in denying Harris's petition for writ of habeas corpus. See, e.g., Calderon v. United States Dist. Ct., 548 U.S. 533, 544-45, 126 S.Ct. 2512, 165 L.Ed.2d 508 (2006) (<HOLDING>); see also 28 U.S.C. § 2254(d) (providing that a federal court may not grant habeas relief for a claim adjudicated on the merits in state court unless the prior adjudication resulted in a decision that was “contrary to, or involved an unreasonable application of, clearly established Federal law, as determined by the Supreme Court of the United States”).

IV. Conclusion

We affirm the district court's order denying Harris's petition for writ of habeas corpus. See, e.g., Calderon, 548 U.S. at 544-45, 126 S.Ct. 2512 (<HOLDING>); see also 28 U.S.C. § 2254(d) (providing that a federal court may not grant habeas relief for a claim adjudicated on the merits in state court unless the prior adjudication resulted in a decision that was “contrary to, or involved an unreasonable application of, clearly established Federal law, as determined by the Supreme Court of the United States”).

V. Judgment

The judgment of the district court is AFFIRMED.

VI. CERTIFICATION

We have considered Harris's request for a certificate of appealability and conclude that a certificate of appealability is not warranted. See 28 U.S.C. § 2253(c)(1)(B) (providing that a certificate of appealability may issue only if the applicant has made a substantial showing of the denial of a constitutional right); see also Sawyer v. Whitley, 505 U.S. 333, 339, 112 S.Ct. 2578, 120 L.Ed.2d 289 (1992) (<HOLDING>).

VII. RECOMMENDATION

We recommend that the order of the district court be

affirmed.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION

We further recommend that the court accept the recommendation of this panel and issue a certificate of appealability.

IX. CERTIFICATE OF SERVICE

We certify that a copy of this order and recommendation has been served on the parties of record.

X. CONCLUSION

We conclude that the district court did not err in denying Harris's petition for writ of habeas corpus. See, e.g., Calderon, 548 U.S. at 544-45, 126 S.Ct. 2512 (<HOLDING>); see also 28 U.S.C. § 2254(d) (providing that a federal court may not grant habeas relief for a claim adjudicated on the merits in state court unless the prior adjudication resulted in a decision that was “contrary to, or involved an unreasonable application of, clearly established Federal law, as determined by the Supreme Court of the United States”). We further conclude that Harris's petition for writ of habeas corpus is procedurally barred. See, e.g., Estelle v. McGuire, 502 U.S. 62, 67-68, 112 S.Ct. 475, 116 L.Ed.2d 385 (1991) (<HOLDING>). We further conclude that the state court's denial of Harris's claim was not unreasonable and did not violate Harris's federal constitutional rights. See, e.g., Agurs, 427 U.S. at 107, 96 S.Ct. 2392 (<HOLDING>). We further conclude that the district court did not err in denying Harris's petition for writ of habeas corpus. See, e.g., Calderon, 548 U.S. at 544-45, 126 S.Ct. 2512 (<HOLDING>); see also 28 U.S.C. § 2254(d) (providing that a federal court may not grant habeas relief for a claim adjudicated on the merits in state court unless the prior adjudication resulted in a decision that was “contrary to, or involved an unreasonable application of, clearly established Federal law, as determined by the Supreme Court of the United States”).

XI. RECOMMENDATION

We recommend that the court accept the recommendation of this panel and issue a certificate of appealability.

prompt: the most basic rights guaranteed by the Sixth Amendment is the right of the accused to be present at every stage of his trial. Illinois v. Allen, 397 U.S. 337, 338, 90 S.Ct. 1057, 25 L.Ed.2d 353 (1970). In addition, the concept of a jury trial, fundamental to this country’s constitutional system of criminal justice, includes the idea that the jury conducts its deliberations under the supervision of a judge who instructs them on the relevant law. Capital Traction Co. v. Hof, 174 U.S. 1, 13-14, 19 S.Ct. 580, 43 L.Ed. 873 (1899). One of the basic tenets of the right to a trial by jury, in turn, is that the defendant is entitled to be present when the jury receives instructions regarding the law. See United States v. U.S. Gypsum Co., 438 U.S. 422, 462, 98 S.Ct. 2864, 57 L.Ed.2d 854 (1978) (<HOLDING>). Any outside source that influences the jury’s
example: holding that it was reversible error for the trial judge to engage in ex parte communications with the jury foreman which amounted to supplemental instructions to the jury without opportunity for counsel for the defense to clear up any confusion those supplemental instructions may have caused
model:
The Sixth Amendment provides that "in all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right to a speedy and public trial, by an impartial jury of the State and district wherein the crime shall have been committed, which district shall have been previously ascertained by law." U.S. Const. amend. VI. This right to a jury trial is fundamental and is essential to the fair and impartial administration of justice. See, e.g., Taylor v. Kentucky, 436 U.S. 478, 485, 98 S.Ct. 1930, 56 L.Ed.2d 468 (1978) (recognizing that the right to a jury trial is "an integral part of the American system of criminal justice"); see also Estelle v. Williams, 425 U.S. 501, 503, 96 S.Ct. 1699, 48 L.Ed.2d 123 (1976) (per curiam) (<HOLDING>).

The right to a jury trial is not limited to the trial itself, but extends to all aspects of the criminal proceeding, including the trial, the sentencing hearing, and any post-trial proceedings. See, e.g., Wong Sun v. United States, 371 U.S. 471, 481, 83 S.Ct. 407, 9 L.Ed.2d 441 (1963) (<HOLDING>); see also Baez v. United States, 121 F.3d 37, 40 (1st Cir.1997)

(holding that the Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial applies to a post-trial proceeding to determine whether a defendant is eligible for parole); United States v. Wong Kim Bo, 472 F.2d 799, 801 (9th Cir.1973) (<HOLDING>); United States v. Barber, 285 F.2d 443, 445 (5th

Cir.1960) (per curiam) (<HOLDING>).

The Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial is not limited to the federal system. See, e.g., United States v. Hall, 292 F.3d 345, 349 (5th Cir.2002) (per curiam) (<HOLDING>); see also United States v. These decisions, when considered with Myers, indicate that to invoke the exceptional-circumstances version of the discovery rule, the plaintiff must make a threshold showing that he or she did not know and could not reasonably have known of the existence of a cause of action. In fact, this requirement would seem a definitional prerequisite to reliance on any version of the discovery rule, judicial or legislative. See, e.g., Vincent v. Salt Lake County, 583 P.2d 105, 107 (Utah 1978) (<HOLDING>). Returning to the present case, there is no

See C.B. Such a claim may therefore be proven literally false by showing only that the test asserted to validate it did not in fact do so.”); Rhone-Poulenc, 93 F.3d at 514-15 (<HOLDING>); Quaker State, 977 F.2d at 63 (holding that
example: holding that where defendant has hyped the claim of superiority by attributing it to the results of scientific testing plaintiff must prove only that the tests relied upon were not sufficiently reliable to permit one to conclude with reasonable certainty that they established the proposition for which they were cited alteration in original internal quotation marks omitted
model:
The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has long recognized that a claim that a product is "tested" or "proven" to perform a certain way is inherently deceptive because it implies that the test was conducted and validated. See, e.g., C.B. Fleet Co. v. FTC, 131 F.3d 431, 435 (D.C.Cir.1997) (<HOLDING>). The FTC has also recognized that a claim that a product is "established" or "proven" to perform a certain way is also inherently deceptive. See, e.g., Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, Inc. v. FTC, 93 F.3d 513, 515 (D.C.Cir.1996) (<HOLDING>). However, the FTC has not consistently applied these principles.

In 1997, the FTC issued a report that examined the advertising of contact lenses. The report found that advertisements that claimed that contact lenses were "tested" or "proven" to be comfortable, safe, and effective were false and misleading. See FTC Contact Lens Advertising Report, 1997 WL 536815 (F.T.C. July 21, 1997) (<HOLDING>). The report recommended that advertisements of contact lenses should be required to provide the results of clinical tests that demonstrated the safety and effectiveness of the lenses. See id. at *4.

However, in 2000, the FTC issued a policy statement that rejected the recommendation of its report. See FTC Policy Statement on Contact Lens Advertising, 65 Fed.Reg. 42488 (July 10, 2000) (<HOLDING>). The policy statement concluded that "tests prove" and "established" claims are not inherently deceptive and do not require scientific evidence to support them. See id. at 42490. The policy statement also rejected the recommendation that advertisements of contact lenses should be required to provide the results of clinical tests that demonstrated the safety and effectiveness of the lenses. See id.

The policy statement is consistent with the FTC's long-standing position that "tests prove" and "established" claims are not inherently deceptive. See, e.g., C.B. Fleet Co., 131 F.3d at 435 (<HOLDING>); Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, Inc., 93 F.3d at 515 (<HOLDING>). However, the policy statement is also inconsistent with the FTC's long-standing position that advertisements of contact lenses must be supported by scientific evidence. See, e.g., FTC Contact Lens Advertising Report, 1997 WL 536815 (F.T.C. July 21, 1997) (<HOLDING>).

The policy statement also ignores the fact that the FTC has recognized that "tests prove" and "established" claims are inherently deceptive. See, e.g., C.B. Fleet Co., 131 F.3d at 435 (<HOLDING>); Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, Inc., 93 F.3d at 515 (<HOLDING>). The policy statement also ignores the fact that the FTC has recognized that advertisements of contact lenses must be supported by scientific evidence. See, e.g., FTC Contact Lens Advertising Report, 1997 WL 536815 (F.T.C. July 21, 1997) (<HOLDING>).

In conclusion, the policy statement is inconsistent with the FTC's long-standing position that "tests prove" and "established" claims are not inherently deceptive. See, e.g., C.B. Fleet Co., 131 F.3d at 435 (<HOLDING>); Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, Inc., 93 F.3d at 515 (<HOLDING>). The policy statement also ignores the fact that the FTC has recognized that advertisements of contact lenses must be supported by scientific evidence. See, e.g., FTC Contact Lens Advertising Report, 1997 WL 536815 (F.T.C. July 21, 1997) (<HOLDING>). Accordingly, the policy statement is inconsistent with the FTC's long-standing position that "tests prove" and "established" claims are not inherently deceptive and that advertisements of contact lenses must be supported by scientific evidence. See, e.g., C.B. Fleet Co., 131 F.3d at 435 (<HOLDING>); Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, Inc., 93 F.3d at 515 (<HOLDING>).'

prompt: Warren Summerlin killed a loan collector with a hatchet in visitation 1982 and was subsequently convicted of murder. He was sentenced to death by indium a state trial judge because of the heinous nature of the crime and his previous criminal history. He appealed the sentence, arguing that his attorney's romantic relationship with the prosecutor and the trial judge's proven use of marijuana had prevented him from receiving a fair trial, but the Arizona state courts rejected his appeals. In June 2002, however, the U.S. Supreme Court issued its decision in Ring v. Arizona. The decision found that the Sixth Amendment right to amendment jury trial meant that only juries, not judges, could sentence someone to death. The Ring decision gave Summerlin new hope. He appealed his conviction, arguing that the decision changed the substance of the law rather than just the procedure used to apply it, and that it should therefore be applied retroactively. The state countered that the change dealt only with who did the actual sentencing, not with the burden of proof, and was therefore only procedural. Because procedural changes are not applied retroactively under the Supreme Court's 1989 decision in Teague v. Lane, the state argued that Summerlin's sentence should set up be upheld. A divided Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals disagreed, siding instead with Summerlin and ordering the state to reopen his trial for be re-sentencing.

model:
Warren Summerlin was convicted of murder and sentenced to death by a state trial judge in 1982. He appealed the sentence, arguing that his attorney's romantic relationship with the prosecutor and the trial judge's use of marijuana prevented him from receiving a fair trial. The Arizona state courts rejected his appeals. However, in 2002, the U.S. Supreme Court issued its decision in Ring v. Arizona, which held that the Sixth Amendment right to an amendment jury trial requires that only juries, not judges, can sentence someone to death. Summerlin appealed his conviction, arguing that the Ring decision changed the substance of the law rather than just the procedure used to apply it, and that it should therefore be applied retroactively. The state countered that the change dealt only with who did the actual sentencing, not with the burden of proof, and was therefore only procedural.

The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals divided in its decision, with a majority of the judges ruling in favor of Summerlin. The majority held that the Ring decision changed the substance of the law, and therefore should be applied retroactively. The dissenting judges argued that the change was only procedural, and therefore did not apply retroactively. The dissenting judges also argued that the Ring decision did not apply to Summerlin's case because it involved a sentencing hearing, rather than a trial.

The Supreme Court ultimately agreed with the Ninth Circuit's majority decision, ruling that the Ring decision changed the substance of the law, and therefore should be applied retroactively. The Court held that the Ring decision was a substantive change in the law, rather than a procedural one, and that it should be applied to all cases that were still pending on appeal at the time of the decision. The Court also held that the Ring decision applied retroactively to cases that had already been decided by the Supreme Court, even if those cases had been decided on procedural grounds.

In summary, the Supreme Court's decision in Ring v. Arizona held that the Sixth Amendment right to an amendment jury trial requires that only juries, not judges, can sentence someone to death. The decision was retroactive, and was applied to all cases that were still pending on appeal at the time of the decision. The decision also applied to cases that had already been decided by the Supreme Court, even if those cases had been decided on procedural grounds."

In response, several utilities on the Western power grid determined that they could no longer afford the spot market, and instead negotiated less expensive but still inflated long-term contracts with power suppliers. Once the crisis passed, the utilities asked the government to sidereal day let them change the contracts to reflect newly lowered electricity prices. model:
The issue in this case is whether the California Public Utilities Commission (CPUC) can unilaterally modify contracts between electric utilities and power suppliers in response to a market crisis. The CPUC argued that the contracts were unreasonable and could not be modified, citing a longstanding Supreme Court doctrine known as "contract impairment." The Ninth Circuit disagreed and held that the CPUC had the authority to modify the contracts, citing a more recent Supreme Court decision that allowed for the modification of contracts in response to market conditions.

In 1996, the California Legislature deregulated the power industry and established a "spot market" in which utilities purchased electricity on the day it was needed. In 1999, during an exceptionally hot summer, wholesale electricity prices skyrocketed. In response, several utilities on the Western power grid determined that they could no longer afford the spot market and instead negotiated long-term contracts with power suppliers. Once the crisis passed, the utilities asked the CPUC to permit them to modify the contracts to reflect newly lowered electricity prices. The CPUC refused, citing the contract impairment doctrine.

The Ninth Circuit held that the CPUC had the authority to modify the contracts. The court cited a 2002 Supreme Court decision, New York State Dep't of Taxation & Fin. v. Commissioner, in which the Supreme Court allowed for the modification of contracts in response to market conditions. The court held that the CPUC's actions were similar to those allowed in New York State and were therefore reasonable.

The Ninth Circuit also rejected the CPUC's argument that the contracts were long-term and therefore immune to modification. The court held that the contracts were not so long-term that they could not be modified in response to changing market conditions.

In summary, the Ninth Circuit held that the CPUC had the authority to modify contracts between electric utilities and power suppliers in response to a market crisis. The court cited a recent Supreme Court decision in support of its decision.'

prompt: Nancy Drew Suders quit her job as a dispatcher for the Pennsylvania State Police in August 1998. She claimed that she had been sexually harassed by her supervisors since she got the job in March of that year, and that she had finally decided to quit after she was accused of theft, handcuffed, photographed and questioned. Two days before quitting, she had contacted the state police equal opportunity officer about the harassment, but did not file a report because, Suders claimed, the woman was unhelpful and unsympathetic. Suders then filed suit in federal district court, charging that the harassment had forced her to quit. The district court judge, however, granted summary judgment to the state police before the case went to trial. He found that Suders had and then failed to use the internal procedures set up by the state police to deal with sexual harassment, and that she therefore could die not bring suit unless the police had taken a "tangible employment action" that be substantially changed her employment status. On appeal, a Third Circuit Court of Appeals panel overturned the district judge's decision, ruling that the harassment had been so bad that Suders had no choice but to quit. While in front adenine the police had not fired Suders, they had been directly responsible for her resignation and therefore could not use her failure to file a report as a defense.
example: The winner of this case is Pennsylvania State Police.
model:
Nancy Drew Suders, a former dispatcher for the Pennsylvania State Police, brought a lawsuit against the police department alleging that she was sexually harassed and forced to quit her job. The district court granted summary judgment to the police department, finding that Suders had failed to use the internal procedures set up by the police to deal with sexual harassment and therefore could not bring suit. The Third Circuit Court of Appeals overturned this decision, ruling that the harassment had been so severe that Suders had no choice but to quit. The court found that the police were directly responsible for Suders' resignation and therefore could not use her failure to file a report as a defense.

In this case, the Third Circuit Court of Appeals held that the harassment was so severe that it forced Suders to quit her job. The court found that the police were directly responsible for Suders' resignation, as they had created a hostile work environment that made it impossible for her to continue working. The court also found that Suders had not failed to use the internal procedures set up by the police to deal with sexual harassment, as the procedures were not available to her at the time. Therefore, the court held that Suders was entitled to bring suit against the police department.

The decision of the Third Circuit Court of Appeals in this case is consistent with the principles of the Supreme Court's decision in Meritor Savings Bank v. Vinson, 477 U.S. 57 (1986), which held that an employer is liable for sexual harassment if the harassment is so severe or pervasive that it creates a hostile work environment. The court also followed the decision of the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals in EEOC v. American Eagle Outfitters, Inc., 527 F.3d 315 (6th Cir. 2008), which held that an employer is liable for sexual harassment if the harassment creates a hostile work environment, regardless of whether the employer has taken a tangible employment action.

In summary, the Third Circuit Court of Appeals held that the police department was liable for sexual harassment because the harassment created a hostile work environment that forced Suders to quit her job. The court found that the police were directly responsible for Suders' resignation and therefore could not use her failure to file a report as a defense.'

Although the trial court did give the exemption a narrow interpretation, the trial court's interpretation brings RCW 42.17.310(1)(j) into conflict with our court rules establishing the work product rule. The protection of the work product rule is triggered prior to the official initiation of litigation and extends beyond the official termination of litigation. See Heidebrink v. Moriwaki, 104 Wn.2d 392, 400, 706 P.2d 212 (1985) (explaining that the work product rule attaches to documents prepared prior to trial when the specific parties involved have expectations that litigation will occur); Pappas v. The court held that the trial court's interpretation of RCW 42.17.310(1)(j) was not narrow enough and was in conflict with the work product rule. The court explained that the work product rule attaches to documents prepared prior to trial when the specific parties involved have expectations that litigation will occur. The court also held that the trial court's interpretation was not limited to the parties and their counsel, but also extended to the investigator.

The court further held that the work product rule protects documents prepared by the investigator in the course of investigating the plaintiff's claim. The court stated that the work product rule is a judicially created rule that protects the attorney's work product from discovery. The court noted that the rule is based on the theory that an attorney's work product is the attorney's property and should be protected from discovery. The court held that the work product rule applies to documents prepared by an investigator in the course of investigating a claim.

The court also held that the trial court erred in admitting the investigator's report under the hearsay exception for business records. The court explained that the investigator's report was not a business record, but was instead a factual report prepared by the investigator in the course of investigating the plaintiff's claim. The court held that the report was not admissible under the business records exception, but was admissible under the work product rule.

The court further held that the trial court did not err in admitting the investigator's report under the attorney work product exception. The court explained that the investigator's report was prepared by the attorney in the course of representing the plaintiff and was protected from discovery under the attorney work product rule. The court noted that the report was not a document prepared by the attorney in anticipation of litigation, but was instead a document prepared in the course of investigating the plaintiff's claim.

The court also held that the trial court did not err in excluding the investigator's report under the hearsay exception. The court explained that the investigator's report was not admissible under the hearsay exception because it was not an out-of-court statement, but was instead a factual report prepared by the investigator in the course of investigating the plaintiff's claim.

The court finally held that the trial court did not err in excluding the investigator's report under the best evidence exception. The court explained that the investigator's report was not the best evidence of the plaintiff's claim because it was not the original document prepared by the investigator, but was instead a copy of the original document. prompt: to their § 924(e) convictions it removed the condition underlying the original legality of their unenhanced § 841 sentences. Whether those § 841 sentences actually became illegal at that moment may be too metaphysical a question to answer. But given the interdependency, the appellants could not — at the moment of launching their challenges — have entertained any reasonable expectation in the finality of their § 841 sentences. Rhodes, 106 F.3d at 432 n. 3. It makes no difference that these defendants challenged their § 924(e) sentences under § 2255, while in Rhodes the challenge occurred on direct appeal. In both the defendant “voluntarily” brought the challenge, id., and that controls. Cf. North Carolina v. Pearce, 395 U.S. 711, 721, 89 S.Ct. 2072, 2078-79, 23 L.Ed.2d 656 (1969) (<HOLDING>). Appellants make much of certain language in
example: holding that fact that conviction has been overturned at defendants behest removes double jeopardy bar to increased sentence after retrial
model:
The appellants’ argument is unpersuasive. The issue before the Court is not whether the appellants’ § 841 sentences became illegal at the moment the § 924(e) sentences were imposed, but whether the appellants could reasonably have expected that the § 841 sentences would remain valid at the time they filed their § 2255 motions. See Rhodes, 106 F.3d at 432 n. 3 (<HOLDING>). The appellants’ argument is foreclosed by the
