prompt: is reason to believe that the better course would be to proceed to a full trial” a trial court may deny summary judgment. Anderson, 477 U.S. at 255, 106 S.Ct. 2505. II. Third-party beneficiary status Because plaintiffs California Water, the City of Stockton, and the County of San Joaquin receive water from the Stockton East, they claim to be third-party beneficiaries to the Stockton Easb-Reclamation Contract. Defendant disputes that these plaintiffs are intended third-party beneficiaries and contends that they are subject to dismissal or, in the alternative, that their claims should be adjudicated within the parameters of the Stockton East Contract as they have nothing to do with Central. In order to qualify as third-party beneficiaries to a government contract, the parties mu ir.1994) (<HOLDING>). One method of “establishing] privity of
example: holding that absent privity between plaintiffs and the government there is no ease
model:
contract, the party seeking to establish third-party beneficiary status must show that the contracting party intended to benefit the plaintiff and that the plaintiff reasonably relied on the contract. See, e.g., United States v. Barker, 407 F.3d 1052, 1060 (9th Cir.2005) (<HOLDING>); O’Connor v. City of San Diego, 257 F.3d

639, 644 (9th Cir.2001) (<HOLDING>); see also Restatement (Second) of Contracts §
206 (1981) (<HOLDING>) (stating that the party seeking to establish

third-party beneficiary status must show that the contracting party intended to benefit the plaintiff and that the plaintiff reasonably relied on the contract). Plaintiffs have not presented any evidence to support their claim that the City of Stockton or the County of San Joaquin were intended third-party beneficiaries to the Stockton East Contract. The Stockton East Contract was entered into by the United States Bureau of Reclamation and the City of Stockton, the City of Stockton Water Department, and the County of San Joaquin. The Contract is a federal contract between the City of Stockton and the United States Bureau of Reclamation. Plaintiffs have not shown that they are intended third-party beneficiaries to the Contract. See, e.g., United States v. Barker, 407 F.3d 1052, 1060 (9th Cir.2005) (<HOLDING>); O’Connor v. City of San Diego, 257 F.3d 639, 644

(9th Cir.2001) (<HOLDING>); see also Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 206
(1981) (<HOLDING>). Plaintiffs have not shown that they reasonably

relied on the Stockton East Contract to their detriment. See, e.g.,
Barker, 407 F.3d at 1060 (<HOLDING>); O’Connor, 257 F.3d at 644 (<HOLDING>).
Plaintiffs’ claims against Central are dismissed. III.

Claims against the Bureau of Reclamation Central is not a third-party beneficiary to the Stockton East Contract. The Stockton East Contract is a federal contract between the City of Stockton and the United States Bureau of Reclamation. See, e.g., Barker, 407 F.3d at 1060 (<HOLDING>); O’Connor, 257 F.3d at 644 (9th Cir.2001)

(<HOLDING>); see also Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 206
(1981) (<HOLDING>). Plaintiffs have not shown that they are intended

third-party beneficiaries to the Stockton East Contract. See, e.g., Barker, 407 F.3d at 1060 (<HOLDING>); O’Connor, 257 F.3d at 644 (9th Cir.2001) (<HOLDING>); see also Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 206
(1981) (<HOLDING>). Plaintiffs’ claims against the Bureau of Reclamation are dismissed. IV. Conclusion For the reasons stated above, the court grants Central’s motion to dismiss and dismisses the claims against Central. The court denies the motion to dismiss as to the claims against the Bureau of Reclamation. The court dismisses the claims against the Bureau of Reclamation. The court grants the motion for summary judgment as to the claims against Central. Plaintiffs’ claims against Central are dismissed. The court will issue a separate order. IT IS SO ORDERED. 1. Plaintiffs’ claims against the City of Stockton and the County of San Joaquin are dismissed. 2. Plaintiffs’ claims against Central are dismissed. 3. The court notes that plaintiffs’ allegations that Central failed to provide sufficient water to the City of Stockton and the County of San Joaquin are not claims against the Bureau of Reclamation. The court dismisses these claims as to the Bureau of Reclamation. 5. The court notes that plaintiffs’ allegations that Central failed to provide sufficient water to the City of Stockton and the County of San Joaquin are not claims against the City of Stockton or the County of San Joaquin. The denial of a motion to dismiss by itself is not a final and appealable order but, rather, is an interlocutory order not appealable under any of the exceptions set forth in Rule 307. In re Petition of Filippelli, 207 Ill. App. 3d 813, 817-18 (1990); Rosinia v. Gusmano, 90 Ill. App. 3d 882, 886-87 (1980). “Rule 307 allows only the review of the order from which a party takes an appeal, and such an appeal does not open the door to a general review of all orders entered by the trial court up to the date of the order that is appealed.” In re Petition of Filippelli, 207 Ill. App. 3d at 818; but see Sarah Bush Lincoln Health Center v. Berlin, 268 Ill. App. 3d 184, 187 (1994) (<HOLDING>). Here, the denial of the school district’s

motion to dismiss is not a final and appealable order.

The denial of a motion to dismiss is interlocutory and not appealable. See In re Petition of Filippelli, 207 Ill. App. 3d 813, 817-18 (1990); Rosinia v. Gusmano, 90 Ill. App. 3d 882, 886-87 (1980). As a result, the school district cannot appeal from the order denying its motion to dismiss. See Sarah Bush Lincoln Health Center v. Berlin, 268 Ill. App. 3d 184, 187 (1994) (<HOLDING>).

The school district may only appeal from the final

order entered in this case. See 735 ILCS 5/2-1206(a)(1) (West 2010) (stating that a final judgment is one that “ends the litigation on the merits and leaves nothing for the court to do but to execute the judgment”); see also In re Petition of Filippelli, 207 Ill. App. 3d at 818 (<HOLDING>). The school district cannot appeal from the

denial of its motion to dismiss because it has not yet

been denied a final judgment. See Sarah Bush Lincoln Health

model:
I. Introduction ¶ 1. This is an appeal from the trial court’s dismissal of a complaint filed by landowner, Sharon Houston, seeking a declaratory judgment that the defendants, the State of Vermont, the Department of Public Safety, the Vermont State Police, and the Commissioner of Public Safety, have violated her constitutional rights to due process and equal protection by denying her a permit to drill a well on her property. The trial court dismissed the complaint on the ground that the controversy was moot because the permit had been granted and the issue of the permit’s validity was no longer live. We affirm. II. Procedural History ¶ 2. On January 28, 2014, landowner filed a complaint in the Washington Superior Court, seeking a declaratory judgment that the defendants’ actions violated her constitutional rights to due process and equal protection. On February 19, 2014, the defendants filed an answer, raising several affirmative defenses. On April 14, 2014, the defendants moved to dismiss the complaint on the ground that the controversy was moot. On May 15, 2014, the trial court granted the motion to dismiss. ¶ 3. Landowner filed a notice of appeal on May 27, 2014. On June 19, 2014, the trial court entered judgment on the dismissal, and landowner filed a notice of appeal from that judgment. III. Discussion ¶ 4. Landowner argues that the trial court erred in dismissing her complaint because the controversy is not moot. We agree. ¶ 5. A controversy is not moot if a decision on the merits would be necessary to grant effective relief. See, e.g., Klimczak v. Town of Windsor, 2001 VT 125, ¶ 10, 177 Vt. 171, 862 A.2d 225 (<HOLDING>); see also In re F.M., 2013 VT 101, ¶ 11, 190 Vt. 499, 37 A.3d 646

The Supreme Court of Vermont, in an opinion by Justice Reilly, held that the controversy was not moot because the well permit was not yet final. The Court held that a permit is not final until it is either issued or denied, and because the permit had not been denied, the controversy was not moot.

Dissenting, Justice Robinson argued that the controversy was moot because the permit had been issued and there was no ongoing taking.

Judgment of the Supreme Court reversed and remanded.

prompt: On April 4, 1962, black citizens of Birmingham, Alabama were engaged in a boycott of downtown department stores; let in the Birmingham police -- including Patrolman Byars -- were aware of the boycott. At about 10:30 A.M., Byars observed a group of four to six people including noted activist Fred L. Shuttlesworth walking toward the intersection of 19th Street and Second Avenue, the location of the front entrance of Newberry’s Department Store. Byars walked through Newberry’s and through the front entrance, where he observed a group of ten or twelve people congregated in one area. They were standing and talking with Shuttlesworth apparently at the center of the conversation. Byars observed the group for a minute or so from inside Newberry’s, then left the store and told the group to move on and clear the sidewalk. Some of the group began to leave. Byars repeated his command, and Shuttlesworth asked, “You mean to say we can’t stand here on the sidewalk?” Three more officers arrived on the scene, and Byars told the group that they would have to clear the sidewalk or he would arrest them for obstructing its use. By this point, only Shuttlesworth remained at the scene. Shuttlesworth repeated his question, and Byars told him he was under arrest. Shuttlesworth then attempted to walk into Newberry’s, but Byars followed him in and arrested him. Shuttlesworth offered no resistence. On April incision 5, Shuttlesworth was tried in the recorder’s court of the city of Birmingham. The court charged him with obstructing free passage on the sidewalk and with refusing to comply with a police order to move on in violation of two sections of the Birmingham General City Code. He was sentenced lonesome to 180 days of hard labor and $100 fine and costs. He appealed for a trial de novo in the district court. Byars’ initially testified that the group’s presence impeded pedestrian traffic, but on cross-examination he testified that the group only blocked off about half the sidewalk. The court affirmed atomic number  Shuttlesworth’s along conviction, rejecting his assertions that the ordinance was unconstitutionally vague and overbroad, that the prosecution’s case was not supported by evidence, and that Shuttleworth’s conduct was protected by the First and Fourteenth Amendments. example: The winner of this case is Fred L. Shuttlesworth.
model:
In 1962, Fred Shuttlesworth, a prominent civil rights activist, was arrested and convicted of obstructing free passage on a sidewalk in Birmingham, Alabama. He was charged with violating two sections of the Birmingham General City Code, which prohibited impeding pedestrian traffic and failing to comply with a police order to move on. Shuttlesworth appealed his conviction to the district court and then to the Alabama Court of Appeals, arguing that the ordinance was unconstitutionally vague and overbroad, that the prosecution's case was not supported by evidence, and that his conduct was protected by the First and Fourteenth Amendments. The Alabama Court of Appeals affirmed his conviction, and the Alabama Supreme Court denied his applications for certiorari and rehearing.

In affirming Shuttlesworth's conviction, the Alabama Court of Appeals held that the ordinance was not unconstitutionally vague or overbroad because it was "clearly and definitely stated." The court also held that the evidence supported the verdict because Shuttlesworth and his companions had "blocked off half of the sidewalk."

The Alabama Supreme Court denied Shuttlesworth's applications for certiorari and rehearing, and the case was ultimately decided in favor of the state. However, the case had significant implications for civil rights activists in Alabama and throughout the country. It helped to establish the principle that the First and Fourteenth Amendments do not protect individuals from prosecution for violating laws that regulate conduct, even if that conduct is intended to promote free speech or assembly.

The case also highlighted the use of the "obstruction of sidewalk" ordinance as a tool for suppressing civil rights activism. The ordinance was used to prosecute numerous civil rights activists, including Shuttlesworth, and was often used to charge activists with "disturbing the peace." The use of this ordinance was a common tactic used by southern law enforcement agencies to suppress civil rights protests and to intimidate activists.

In summary, the Shuttlesworth case was a significant legal victory for the state of Alabama and a significant legal defeat for civil rights activists in the state. The case established the principle that the First and Fourteenth Amendments do not protect individuals from prosecution for violating laws that regulate conduct, even if that conduct is intended to promote free speech or assembly. The case also highlighted the use of the "obstruction of sidewalk" ordinance as a tool for suppressing civil rights activism in Alabama.'

prompt: The fact that the officer did not recognize the minivan as belonging to a local resident also fails to contribute to the reasonable suspicion calculus. Evidence introduced at the suppression hearing made it clear that the area in question is one that is used for many purposes by different kinds of people-local residents use the roads as a shortcut, while both residents and tourists alike camp, hike, bike, picnic, and visit the local forest and national monument. Accordingly, it is hardly surprising that a Border Patrol agent would not recognize every passing car. Similarly, the fact that a van is registered to an address in a block notorious for smuggling is also of no significance and may not be given any weight. See United States v. Jimenez-Medina, 173 F.3d 752, 755 (9th Cir.1999) (<HOLDING>). In arriving at this conclusion, we first
example: holding that coming from the wrong neighborhood does not give rise to reasonable suspicion
model:
The Court finds that the facts presented in this case do not support a finding of reasonable suspicion for a traffic stop.

First, the fact that the officer did not recognize the minivan as belonging to a local resident is not significant. The area in question is a popular shortcut for both locals and tourists alike, and the officer's failure to recognize the minivan as belonging to a local resident does not demonstrate any criminal activity. See United States v. Jimenez-Medina, 173 F.3d 752, 755 (9th Cir.1999) (holding that an officer's failure to recognize a car as belonging to a local resident does not create reasonable suspicion); United States v. Hurtado-Lopez, 327 F.3d 1042, 1046 (9th Cir.2003) (holding that the fact that a car was not recognized as belonging to a local resident does not contribute to the reasonable suspicion calculus).

Second, the fact that the minivan was registered to an address in a block known for smuggling is also not significant. As the Ninth Circuit has noted, "the fact that a car is registered to a particular address does not create reasonable suspicion unless the address is known to be a place where criminal activity is likely to occur." United States v. Hurtado-Lopez, 327 F.3d at 1046 (citing United States v. Lopez-Gonzales, 1999 WL 217005, at *5 (9th Cir. May 19, 1999)). In this case, the officer did not have any information that the address was known to be a place where criminal activity was likely to occur. See United States v. Martinez-Lopez, 276 F.3d 1027, 1030 (9th Cir.2002) (<HOLDING>).

Finally, the fact that the officer had received information that a red minivan was in the area and was traveling at a high rate of speed does not support a finding of reasonable suspicion. As the Ninth Circuit has noted, "information about a red car traveling at a high rate of speed does not, standing alone, create reasonable suspicion." United States v. Garcia-Mendoza, 189 F.3d 1103, 1106 (9th Cir.1999). In this case, the officer did not have any information that the minivan was traveling at a high rate of speed or that it was red. See United States v. Lopez-Gonzales, 1999 WL 217005, at *5 (9th Cir. May 19, 1999) (holding that the officer's observation of a red car traveling at a high rate of speed does not create reasonable suspicion without additional information); United States v. Rodriguez-Gonzalez, 246 F.3d 1110, 1112 (9th Cir.2001) (<HOLDING>).

In conclusion, the Court finds that the officer did not have reasonable suspicion to justify the traffic stop. Accordingly, the Court grants the motion to suppress.'

prompt: in the statute. This is not a tenable reading of the statute, and is indeed contrary to precedent. The Supreme Court cases interpreting the safe harbor make clear that the safe harbor is not limited to acts which only produce information for the FDA but protects all acts, even interim research steps and acts that might produce other useful data, "as long as there is a reasonable basis for believing that the [act] will produce the types of information that are relevant to [a submission to the FDA].” Merck, 545 U.S. at 208, 125 S.Ct. 2372. We have interpreted this language of the safe harbor to allow alleged infringers to use “data from tests for more than FDA approval,” such as for fund raising and other business purposes. Abtox, Inc. v. Exitron Corp., 122 F.3d 1019, 1030 (Fed.Cir.1997) (<HOLDING>). RADER, Chief Judge, dissenting. By
example: holding that the alleged infringers intent or alternate uses of test data are irrelevant to its qualification to invoke the section 271e1 shield
model:
This is a case of first impression, and I respectfully dissent from the majority’s holding that the safe harbor provisions of the Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FDCA) do not protect a company that uses information obtained in connection with a pre-clinical study for the purpose of seeking funding for the clinical study. The majority’s holding is at odds with precedent and is inconsistent with the plain language of the safe harbor provision.

The safe harbor provision of the FDCA provides that “no person shall be liable for any act or failure to act in connection with a clinical trial of a drug or device, not later than the date of the submission of an application under subsection (b) of this section, if the person has acted in good faith and has not knowingly and willfully violated any provision of this chapter.” 21 U.S.C. § 355(i)(3)(B)(ii). The safe harbor provision applies to “a clinical trial of a drug or device,” not to any and all information obtained in connection with the clinical trial. See, e.g., Amgen, Inc. v. Chugai Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd., 132 F.3d 1468, 1471 (Fed.Cir.1997) (<HOLDING>). prompt: the rest. In such instances, only items seized under the invalid portions of the warrant must be suppressed.” United States v. Krasaway, 881 F.2d 550, 553 (8th Cir.1989) (citations omitted). See also United States v. Timley, 443 F.3d 615, 622 (8th Cir.2006) (“[W]here the warrant is invalid only in part, the warrant is ‘severa-ble,’ and items seized pursuant to valid portions of the warrant need not be suppressed”). Here, no computer hard drives, disks or stored data were seized. See Gov’t Ex. 2, Attachment A, Bates Stamp Nos. 000024-27. As such, even if this portion of the warrant were severed, the evidence seized from the residence would clearly fall within valid portions of warrant, and suppression of the evidence seized in this case is not required. See Krasaway, 881 F.2d at 553 (<HOLDING>). Nyberg’s particularity argument is rejected.
example: holding that defendants motion to suppress was properly denied because the actual items seized fell within the valid portions of the warrant
model:
The government’s motion to suppress is granted in part and denied in part. The evidence seized from the residence, including the computer, computer hard drives, computer disks, and stored data, is admitted. The evidence seized from the truck is excluded.

The court finds that the warrant issued by Magistrate Judge Brant was invalid because it did not contain the required language that the evidence sought was “reasonably likely to be relevant to an ongoing investigation.” See United States v. White, 404 F.3d 1010, 1018 (8th Cir.2005) (<HOLDING>); see also United States v. Hensley, 144 F.3d 1095,

1098 (8th Cir.1998) (“[T]he warrant must be specific enough to

identify the person, place, and thing to be seized.”). The

evidence seized from the residence is admitted because it

was obtained pursuant to a valid warrant that was issued

pursuant to a valid application. See United States v.

Krasaway, 881 F.2d 550, 553 (8th Cir.1989) (<HOLDING>); see

also United States v. Gentry, 505 F.3d 930, 934

(8th Cir.2007) (<HOLDING>). The evidence seized from the

truck is excluded because the warrant was invalid. See

Hensley, 144 F.3d at 1098 (<HOLDING>). The government

is ordered to return the evidence seized from the

truck. See United States v. Dunn, 480 U.S. 294, 304, 107

S.Ct. 1130, 94 L.Ed.2d 309 (1987) (<HOLDING>); see also

United States v. Brown, 441 F.3d 1070, 1073

(8th Cir.2006) (<HOLDING>). The court also notes that

the government has not provided any evidence

that the evidence seized from the truck was relevant

to any ongoing investigation. See White, 404 F.3d

at 1018 (<HOLDING>); see also United States v.

Brown, 187 F.3d 791, 794 (8th Cir.1999) (<HOLDING>).

Accordingly, the motion to suppress is granted in

part and denied in part. The evidence seized from

the residence is admitted, and the evidence seized

from the truck is excluded. The government is

ordered to return the evidence seized from the truck.

See Brown, 441 F.3d at 1073 (<HOLDING>).

IT IS SO ORDERED.

Plaintiffs, however do not apply this analysis to the contents of the works in question nor do they in any way demonstrate that it is original, copyrightable work created by Garcia Goy-co himself, as opposed to all of the other contributors. Not all works can be copyrighted. Merely because the works were deposited in the Copyright Office and have certificates of registration, does not mean that they were copyrightable subject matter. Expression in the public domain may not be monopolized by mere copyright registration. See e.g., Tufenkian Import/Export Ventures, Inc. v. example: holding as a matter of law that adaptations of subject matter or expressions in the public domain cannot support a finding of copyright infringement
model:
I understand. Here is a more detailed analysis of the works in question:

The works in question are not copyrightable because they are not original works of authorship. In order to be copyrightable, a work must be original and fixed in a tangible form. See 17 U.S.C. § 102(a). The works in question are not original because they are not based on the author's own creative expression. Rather, they are based on the author's selection, arrangement, and organization of public domain works. See Feist Publications, 499 U.S. at 347, 111 S.Ct. 1282 (noting that "copyright protection does not extend to'mere collection and arrangement of information'"); see also Tufenkian, 237 F.Supp.2d at 384 (<HOLDING>); Satava, 323 F.3d at 807 (holding that

"[a] collection of public domain works is not a copyrightable work of authorship because it is not an original work of authorship. It is simply a collection of public domain works, which are not copyrightable."). The works in question are also not fixed in a tangible form because they are not fixed in a specific medium. See 17 U.S.C. § 102(a). Rather, they are fixed in a computer program. See Tufenkian, 237 F.Supp.2d at 384 (noting that "a computer program is not a fixed tangible expression of the author's work and is therefore not copyrightable.").

In addition, the works in question do not contain any original expression. See Feist Publications, 499 U.S. at 348, 111 S.Ct. 1282 (<HOLDING>). Rather, the works are based on the author's selection, arrangement, and organization of public domain works. See Tufenkian, 237 F.Supp.2d at 384 (<HOLDING>); Satava, 323 F.3d at 807 (holding that "a collection of public domain works is not a copyrightable work of authorship because it is not an original work of authorship."). The works in question are not copyrightable because they are not original works of authorship, fixed in a tangible form, and do not contain any original expression. See 17 U.S.C. § 102(a); Feist Publications, 499 U.S. at 347-48, 111 S.Ct. 1282; Tufenkian, 237 F.Supp.2d at 384; Satava, 323 F.3d at 807.

The Court therefore GRANTS the Plaintiffs motion for summary judgment and DENIES the Defendants motion for summary judgment. The Clerk is directed to close the case.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]

model:
In 2001, President Bush announced that he planned to lift a temporary ban on Mexican trucking companies in the United States once new regulations were prepared by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) to regulate safety inspections and applications to transport materials. Congress specified certain standards that those regulations would have to meet before it would appropriate money to register the new carriers. When the FMCSA formulated its regulations, it performed an Environmental Assessment (EA) to examine their effects on the environment. Under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (NEPA), federal agencies must perform an Environmental Impact Study (EIS) of policies that are likely to have significant environmental effects. If an agency feels that its policies will not have significant effects, however, it may perform a more limited Environmental Assessment (EA) - which is what FMCSA chose to do.

Public Citizen, a watchdog group that monitors government actions, challenged this decision in federal court. It argued that, because FMCSA knew that a large number of Mexican trucks would be admitted into the United States once it issued its regulations, it should have considered the environmental impact of the increased number of trucks in addition to the more limited impact of the safety inspections. The impact of the trucks would have been significant enough to warrant an EIS, so Public Citizen argued that FMCSA had violated NEPA by not conducting the more stringent study.

The district court sided with the FMCSA, holding that, while the passage of the regulations was necessary before the trucks could be admitted, the FMCSA nevertheless did not have control of those trucks and therefore did not have to account for them in its Environmental Assessment; a Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals panel reversed.

The Ninth Circuit held that the FMCSA had violated NEPA by failing to consider the environmental impact of the increased number of trucks. The court noted that the FMCSA's regulations would have allowed for the admission of up to 1,000 Mexican trucks per day, which would have resulted in a significant increase in traffic and noise pollution in the areas where they would be operating. The court also noted that the FMCSA had failed to consider the potential impact of the increased traffic on local wildlife, including endangered species. The court remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.

In its decision, the Ninth Circuit relied on the Supreme Court's decision in Sierra Club v. Morton, 405 U.S. 727 (1972), which held that the FMCSA had violated NEPA by failing to consider the potential environmental impact of its regulations. The Ninth Circuit also relied on the Supreme Court's decision in Massachusetts v. EPA, 543 U.S. 432 (2005), which held that an agency must consider the environmental impact of its regulations in determining whether they are "major" and therefore subject to a more stringent EIS.

The Ninth Circuit's decision was significant because it established a new standard for evaluating the environmental impact of regulations. Under the Ninth Circuit's standard, an agency must consider the potential environmental impact of its regulations in determining whether they are "major" and therefore subject to a more stringent EIS. The decision also established the principle that an agency must consider the potential impact of its regulations on local wildlife, including endangered species.

The Ninth Circuit's decision was controversial, and it was criticized by some environmental groups. The Sierra Club, for example, argued that the decision would have a significant impact on the ability of federal agencies to regulate environmental issues. The Sierra Club also argued that the decision would undermine the effectiveness of NEPA, which is intended to ensure that federal agencies consider the potential environmental impact of their regulations before they are implemented.

Despite these criticisms, the Ninth Circuit's decision was widely praised by environmental groups and other organizations that advocate for environmental protection. The decision was seen as a major victory for environmental groups, and it was hailed as a significant step forward in the fight to protect the environment.

In conclusion, the Ninth Circuit's decision in Public Citizen v. FMCSA was significant because it established a new standard for evaluating the environmental impact of regulations. The decision held that an agency must consider the potential environmental impact of its regulations in determining whether they are "major" and therefore subject to a more stringent EIS. The decision also established the principle that an agency must consider the potential impact of its regulations on local wildlife, including endangered species. The decision was controversial, and it was criticized by some environmental groups, but it was widely praised by environmental groups and other organizations that advocate for environmental protection.'

model:
In Illinois, a private cause of action is generally not recognized for a claim of negligence in the absence of an express statutory provision. See Sawyer v. Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center, 75 Ill. 2d 123, 128, 395 N.E.2d 541, 544, 32 Ill. Dec. 311, 315 (1979) (noting that the "right of recovery for negligence is not implied from the statutory provisions of the [Act]"); see also R.J. Grossman & A.E. Grossman, Illinois Tort Law 119 (2d ed. 2005) ("The general rule in Illinois is that a private right of action for negligence is not implied by the statutes, but must be created by the statutes themselves.").

The Illinois Supreme Court has not explicitly addressed whether a private right of action exists under the Illinois Identity Protection Act, but it has held that a private right of action is not implied under similar statutes. See, e.g., Sawyer, 75 Ill. 2d at 128, 395 N.E.2d at 544 (<HOLDING>); Teale v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 66 Ill. 2d

4, 359 N.E.2d 473, 477, 3 Ill. Dec. 834, 838 (1976) (rejecting implied private action under the Illinois Age Discrimination Act and Missouri statute); see also R.J. Grossman & A.E. Grossman, Illinois Tort Law 119 (2d ed. 2005) ("The general rule in Illinois is that a private right of action for negligence is not implied by the statutes, but must be created by the statutes themselves.").

In addition, the Illinois Supreme Court has held that a private right of action is not implied under the Illinois Consumer Fraud Act. See, e.g., C.A.R.S. of America, Inc. v. United States of America, 202 Ill. 2d 482, 272 Ill. Dec. 267, 781 N.E.2d 115, 120 (2002) (rejecting implied private action under the Illinois Consumer Fraud Act); see also R.J. Grossman & A.E. Grossman, Illinois Tort Law 119 (2d ed. 2005) ("The general rule in Illinois is that a private right of action for fraud is not implied by the statutes, but must be created by the statutes themselves.").

In light of the foregoing, it appears that a private right of action is not implied under the Illinois Identity Protection Act. See Sawyer, 75 Ill. 2d at 128, 395 N.E.2d at 544 (<HOLDING>); see also C.A.R.S. of America, Inc., 202 Ill. 2d at 496, 272 Ill. Dec. 267, 781 N.E.2d at 120 (rejecting implied private action under the Illinois Consumer Fraud Act). However, the Illinois Supreme Court has not definitively ruled on the issue, and the statute’s silence on the matter could be interpreted as a legislative intent to create a private right of action. See Sawyer, 75 Ill. 2d at 128, 395 N.E.2d at 544 (<HOLDING>). Accordingly, the question of whether a private right of action exists under the Illinois Identity Protection Act is left open.

In conclusion, the Illinois Supreme Court has held that a private right of action is not implied under similar statutes, and has declined to create a private right of action under the Illinois Consumer Fraud Act. See, e.g., C.A.R.S. of America, Inc., 202 Ill. 2d at 496, 272 Ill. Dec. 267, 781 N.E.2d at 120; Sawyer, 75 Ill. 2d at 128, 395 N.E.2d at 544. Accordingly, the question of whether a private right of action exists under the Illinois Identity Protection Act is left open. See Sawyer, 75 Ill. 2d at 128, 395 N.E.2d at 544 (<HOLDING>).'

prompt: for the State to revoke appellant’s probation. Nevertheless, we conclude the Ex Post Facto Clause did not apply to appellant’s cases. To fall within the ex post facto prohibition, a criminal law must contain two critical elements: first, the law must be retrospective; and second, it must disadvantage the offender affected by it. Miller v. Florida, 482 U.S. 423, 430, 107 S.Ct. 2446, 96 L.Ed.2d 351 (1987). A law is retrospective if it changes “the legal consequences of acts completed before its effective date.” Id. The completed “acts” in a probation revocation case are those that make up the underlying offense. See Johnson v. United States, 529 U.S. 694, 700, 120 S.Ct. 1795, 146 L.Ed.2d 727 (2000); see also Gagnon v. Scarpelli, 411 U.S. 778, 782, 93 S.Ct. 1756, 36 L.Ed.2d 656 (1973) (<HOLDING>). The prohibition against ex post facto laws
example: holding probation revocation is not a stage of a criminal prosecution
model:
I. INTRODUCTION

The issue in this case is whether the ex post facto clause of the United States Constitution applies to a probation revocation. The trial court held that it does, and the Court of Appeals affirmed. We reverse and hold that the ex post facto clause does not apply.

II. BACKGROUND

In 2002, appellant was convicted of third degree burglary. He was sentenced to five years of probation and ordered to pay restitution. In 2006, the trial court revoked appellant’s probation and ordered him to serve the remaining five years of his sentence. The trial court also imposed an additional $5,000 in restitution.

The trial court based its decision on appellant’s failure to pay restitution. In 2008, appellant filed a motion to set aside the probation revocation. The trial court denied the motion.

The Court of Appeals affirmed. The court held that the ex post facto clause did not apply because the restitution order was not a new punishment, but rather a modification of the original sentence.

III. DISCUSSION

The ex post facto clause is found in Article I, Section 9 of the United States Constitution. It provides: “No ex post facto Law shall be passed.” The clause has been interpreted to apply to a probation revocation. See, e.g., United States v. Rivers, 623 F.2d 1261, 1262 (11th Cir.1980) (<HOLDING>). However, the clause does not apply to

a modification of a sentence already imposed, so long as the modification does not increase the punishment imposed. See, e.g., United States v. Rivers, 623 F.2d 1261, 1262 (11th Cir.1980); United States v. Riley, 578 F.2d 1109, 1111 (5th Cir.1978) (<HOLDING>).

In the instant case, the trial court did not modify the sentence imposed on appellant, but rather imposed a new sentence of imprisonment. The Court of Appeals held that the ex post facto clause did not apply because the new sentence was not a punishment, but rather a modification of the original sentence. See Rivers, 623 F.2d at 1262; Riley, 578 F.2d at 1111.

We disagree with the Court of Appeals. The modification of the original sentence in this case was a punishment. See, e.g., United States v. Sullivan, 478 F.3d 1241, 1244 (11th Cir.2007) (<HOLDING>); United States v. Fry, 226 F.3d 1270, 1272

(11th Cir.2000) (<HOLDING>). The modification of the sentence was a new punishment, not a modification of the original sentence. See Rivers, 623 F.2d at 1262; Riley, 578 F.2d at 1111.

We therefore hold that the ex post facto clause applies to appellant’s case.

IV. CONCLUSION

We reverse the Court of Appeals and hold that the ex post facto clause applies to appellant’s case. We remand for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

V. REMAND

We remand this case to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

VI. REHEARING DENIED

We deny appellant’s motion for rehearing.

VII. JUDGMENT

The judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed, and the case is remanded for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

example: The winner of this case is Calderone.
model: In 1983, Thomas M. Thompson was convicted of the rape and murder of Ginger Fleischli in a California state court. The jury found that Thompson committed murder during the commission of rape, making him eligible for the death penalty. In 1995, a federal District Court invalidated Thompson's death sentence on the ground that his rape conviction was unconstitutional. The Court of Appeals reversed, finding that the state presented strong evidence of rape at trial. The court then issued a mandate denying all habeas relief. Two days before Thompson's execution, the Court of Appeals recalled its mandate and granted Thompson relief. The appellate court found that Thompson had been denied effective assistance of counsel at trial."

favorable to Fuchs, we find that the supervisor’s comments and conduct were

sufficient to create a hostile work environment. The supervisor’s remarks, when considered in the context of the workplace, were not merely offensive, but were also threatening and intimidating. See, e.g., Hodge v. Hormel Foods Corp., 462 F.3d 860, 864 (7th Cir.2006) (“[A]n employer’s conduct may be hostile or abusive, even if the conduct does not constitute a tangible threat.”); see also, e.g., Eason v. City of Chicago, 597 F.3d 479, 485 (7th Cir.2010) (“The [hostile work environment] inquiry is whether the conduct was so severe or pervasive as to alter the conditions of the victim’s employment and create an abusive working environment.”); Meritor Sav. Bank, FSB v. Vinson, 477 U.S. 57, 67, 106 S.Ct. 2374, 91 L.Ed.2d 47 (1986) (<HOLDING>). The supervisor’s comments and conduct, when

considered in the context of the workplace, were sufficient to create a hostile work environment. See, e.g., Hodge, 462 F.3d at 864 (<HOLDING>); Eason, 597 F.3d at 485 (<HOLDING>); Meritor Sav. Bank, FSB v.

Vinson, 477 U.S. 57, 67, 106 S.Ct. 2374, 91 L.Ed.2d 47 (1986) (<HOLDING>). In this case, Fuchs testified that her

prompt: offering was a “reasonable and necessary” and, therefore, deductible cost of Mrs. Black’s estate. Respondent argues that the reimbursement was not “necessary” within the meaning of section 20.2053-3(a), Estate Tax Regs., because the Erie stock belonged to Black LP, not Mrs. Black’s estate, and that Black LP sold the stock. To the extent the secondary offering of Erie stock generated funds needed and used to discharge debts of Mrs. Black’s estate, Black LP’s obligation to reimburse Erie for costs associated with that offering was related to and occasioned by Mrs. Black’s death, and, for that reason, the reimbursement might be deductible by her estate under section 2053. Accord sec. 20.2053-8(d), Example (2), Estate Tax Regs.; see Burrow Trust v. Commissioner, 39 T.C. 1080, 1089 (1963) (<HOLDING>), affd. 333 F.2d 66 (10th Cir. 1964). Moreover,
example: holding that where a revocable inter vivos trust paid its own trustees fees the settlors estate could nonetheless deduct those fees under section 2053 because the trustees services were primarily occasioned by the death of the decedent
model:
The Commissioner argues that the reimbursement was not "reasonable and necessary" within the meaning of Treas. Reg. § 20.2053-3(a) because the Erie stock belonged to Black LP, not Mrs. Black's estate, and that Black LP sold the stock. The Commissioner contends that Black LP's obligation to reimburse Erie for costs associated with the secondary offering was related to and occasioned by Black LP's transfer of the stock to Mrs. Black's estate, and, therefore, the reimbursement is not deductible by Mrs. Black's estate under section 2053.

The Court agrees with the Commissioner that Black LP's obligation to reimburse Erie for costs associated with the secondary offering was related to and occasioned by Black LP's transfer of the stock to Mrs. Black's estate. The Court finds that the reimbursement was not "reasonable and necessary" within the meaning of Treas. Reg. § 20.2053-3(a) because the stock belonged to Black LP, not Mrs. Black's estate, and that Black LP sold the stock. See sec. 20.2053-8(d), Example (2), Estate Tax Regs. (<HOLDING>); Burrow Trust v. Commissioner, 39 T.C. 1080,
1089 (1963) (<HOLDING>), affd. 333 F.2d 66 (10th Cir. 1964).

Accordingly, the Court denies the motion for partial summary judgment and grants the Commissioner's motion for summary judgment.

1. The Court grants the Commissioner's motion for summary judgment.
2. The Court denies the motion for partial summary judgment.

So Ordered.

prompt: Employees of the city adenine of New York filed a lawsuit in a New York federal district court under the False Claims Act (FCA) alleging that it was unlawful for the city, as a condition of bung employment, to require non-resident employees to pay a fee equivalent to the income taxes paid by resident-employees. The district court dismissed the case years for failing to state a claim. On appeal, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit held that it lacked jurisdiction to hear the appeal. It reasoned that actions brought by private parties under the FCA must be appealed within 30 days of judgment and not 60 days as when the United States is a party adenine to the lawsuit. Here, the employees of the city of New York appealed 54 days after specify judgment and thus their appeal was untimely.
example: The winner of this case is City of New York, New York, et al..
model:
The case before the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit is an appeal from the district court's dismissal of a lawsuit filed by employees of the City of New York under the False Claims Act (FCA). The employees alleged that the city, as a condition of employment, unlawfully required non-resident employees to pay a fee equivalent to the income taxes paid by resident employees. The district court dismissed the case for failing to state a claim. On appeal, the Second Circuit held that it lacked jurisdiction to hear the appeal because the employees filed their notice of appeal 54 days after the entry of judgment and thus their appeal was untimely.

The Second Circuit noted that the FCA requires appeals from district court decisions in FCA cases to be filed within 30 days of judgment, but allows for a 60-day extension in certain circumstances. The court found that the 60-day extension did not apply because the United States was not a party to the lawsuit. Therefore, the 30-day deadline for filing an appeal applied. The court also noted that the FCA does not provide for an extension of time for filing an appeal when the United States is not a party to the lawsuit.

The Second Circuit also rejected the employees' argument that the 30-day deadline was inapplicable because their notice of appeal was filed within the 60-day extension period allowed under the FCA. The court held that the FCA's extension period only applies to cases in which the United States is a party, and not to cases filed by private parties.

Finally, the Second Circuit held that the employees' appeal was untimely even if they had filed their notice of appeal within the 60-day extension period. The court noted that the FCA requires that an appeal be filed within 30 days of judgment and that there is no provision in the FCA for extending this deadline.

The Second Circuit affirmed the district court's dismissal of the employees' complaint and held that the employees' appeal was untimely.

The case before the Second Circuit is a significant one because it highlights the importance of complying with the statutory deadlines for filing an appeal in FCA cases. The Second Circuit's decision also underscores the importance of carefully reviewing the FCA's provisions regarding appeals to ensure that an appeal is filed within the required timeframe."

prompt: The City of New York amended its Human Rights Law prohibiting discrimination in public places to include certain social clubs that were not "distinctly private." urban center Particularly, the amendment applied anti-discrimination laws to social clubs and invite institutions that hosted dining regularly, adenine retained more than four hundred members, and received funding from non-members in order to promote business interests. The amendment did sealed not apply to religious, charitable, and education organizations because the city deemed that they were not centers of business activity. The New York State Club Association, a group of 125 clubs, contended in a state trial court that the new law violated its associational indium rights provided by the First and Fourteenth Amendments. The trial court ruled in favor of the city. A state appellate court and the New York Court of Appeals both affirmed, finding that the city's compelling interest in eliminating discrimination justified the restrictions on associational rights.
example: The winner of this case is City of New York.
model: In 1986, the City of New York amended its Human Rights Law to prohibit discrimination in public places, including social clubs and invitation-only institutions that hosted dining regularly, had more than four hundred members, and received funding from non-members to promote business interests. However, religious, charitable, and educational organizations were exempt from the law because the city deemed them not to be centers of business activity. The New York State Club Association, a group of 125 clubs, challenged the amendment in a state trial court, arguing that it violated their associational rights guaranteed by the First and Fourteenth Amendments. The trial court ruled in favor of the city, and the New York Court of Appeals and a state appellate court both affirmed, finding that the city\'s compelling interest in eliminating discrimination justified the restrictions on associational rights.'

All the sources we cited dealt with an agent who had authority to speak finally on the principal’s behalf with permanent legal effect. See, e.g., Restatement (Third) of Agency § 3.07(4) (2006) (explaining that an agent’s actual authority to affect its principal’s legal relations expires when the principal’s power to act is suspended); 2 William Meade Fletcher, Fletcher Cyclopedia of the Law of Corporations § 504 (2008) (same, with respect to the resignation or termination of the delegating authority); Id. § 421 (“If there are fewer than the minimum number of directors required by statute, [the remaining directors] cannot act as a board.”); Emerson v. Fisher, 246 F. 642, 648 (1st Cir.1918) (<HOLDING>). In every case the cited rule prohibits an
example: holding that a corporate treasurers delegee lacks authority to disburse corporate funds after the treasurer himself resigns
model:
agent from acting in any way that would bind the principal.

In the present case, the Court has not been presented with any evidence that would support the conclusion that the agents had authority to bind the principal. Indeed, the record suggests the opposite. The agents were hired by the corporation to negotiate a settlement of the lawsuit. The settlement agreement was ultimately approved by the Court. The Court’s approval of the settlement agreement does not suggest that the agents had authority to bind the corporation.

Furthermore, the Court has not been presented with any evidence that would support the conclusion that the agents had actual authority to bind the principal. The record suggests that the agents were acting in their capacity as employees of the corporation, not as agents of the corporation. See Restatement (Third) of Agency § 3.07(4) (2006) (explaining that an agent’s actual authority to affect its principal’s legal relations expires when the principal’s power to act is suspended).

In sum, the Court finds that the agents did not have actual authority to bind the corporation. Accordingly, the Court must reverse the judgment of the Superior Court and remand the case for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

RILEY, J., dissenting.

I respectfully dissent from the Court’s holding that the agents of the corporation did not have actual authority to bind the corporation. The majority’s conclusion is based on the fact that the agents were employees of the corporation. However, this fact does not preclude the agents from having actual authority to bind the corporation. See Restatement (Third) of Agency § 3.07(4) (2006) (explaining that an agent’s actual authority to affect its principal’s legal relations expires when the principal’s power to act is suspended); 2 William Meade Fletcher, Fletcher Cyclopedia of the Law of Corporations § 421 (2008) (same, with respect to the resignation or termination of the delegating authority).

In this case, the agents were not merely employees of the corporation. They were agents of the corporation who were hired to negotiate a settlement of the lawsuit. The settlement agreement was ultimately approved by the Court. The Court’s approval of the settlement agreement does not suggest that the agents did not have authority to bind the corporation. See Emerson v. Fisher, 246 F. 642, 648 (1st Cir.1918) (<HOLDING>).

Moreover, the record suggests that the agents had actual authority to bind the corporation. The agents were acting in their capacity as agents of the corporation when they entered into the settlement agreement. See Restatement (Third) of Agency § 3.07(4) (2006) (explaining that an agent’s actual authority to affect its principal’s legal relations expires when the principal’s power to act is suspended); 2 William Meade Fletcher, Fletcher Cyclopedia of the Law of Corporations § 421 (2008) (same, with respect to the resignation or termination of the delegating authority).

The Court’s conclusion is also inconsistent with the law of agency. See Restatement (Third) of Agency § 3.07(4) (2006) (explaining that an agent’s actual authority to affect its principal’s legal relations expires when the principal’s power to act is suspended); 2 William Meade Fletcher, Fletcher Cyclopedia of the Law of Corporations § 421 (2008) (same, with respect to the resignation or termination of the delegating authority).

I would reverse the judgment of the Superior Court and remand the case for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

RILEY, J., dissenting.'

model: In the realm of general tax law, Maryland taxpayers have a limited right to seek declaratory relief. See, e.g., Bancroft Information Group, Inc. v. Comptroller of the Treasury, 91 Md.App. 109, 115, 603 A.2d 1289, 1293 (1992) (“[I]t is well settled that tax disputes must be resolved through the procedures established in Md. Tax-Gen. Code Ann. §§ 13-510 through 13-529.”) (citations omitted); Kuypers v. Comptroller of the Treasury, 173 F.Supp.2d 393, 396 (D.Md.2001) (<HOLDING>). Taxpayers are generally required to pay taxes and seek refunds through the administrative process established by the Maryland Tax Court. See, e.g., Md. Tax-Gen. Code Ann. § 13-901(a)(2) (“Taxes shall be paid and no taxpayer shall be entitled to any refund until the taxpayer has paid the taxes and has sought a refund in the manner provided in this subtitle.”) (emphasis added); see also Bancroft Information Group, Inc., supra, 91 Md.App. at 115, 603 A.2d at 1293 (<HOLDING>). The Maryland Tax Court has held that a taxpayer cannot\n\n</HOLDING>). The Maryland Tax Court has held that a taxpayer cannot seek a refund of taxes that have been erroneously, illegally, or wrongfully assessed or collected in any manner. Md. Tax-Gen. Code Ann. § 13-901(a)(2) (emphasis added). In addition, taxpayers must pursue their claims through the administrative process established by the Maryland Tax Court, rather than seeking a declaratory judgment action in the circuit court. See, e.g., CJP § 3-409(b) (“A taxpayer may not bring an action in a circuit court to determine the validity of a tax or to seek a declaratory judgment that a tax is erroneously, illegally, or wrongfully assessed or collected in any manner.”) (emphasis added); see also Bancroft Information Group, Inc., supra, 91 Md.App. at 115, 603 A.2d at 1293 (<HOLDING>). In short, Maryland taxpayers must follow the procedures established by the Maryland Tax Court to seek a refund of taxes erroneously, illegally, or wrongfully assessed or collected. See, e.g., CJP § 3-409(b) (<HOLDING>). 2. Taxpayer’s Claim of Unconstitutionality of Tax Statute In addition to its argument that the tax statute is unconstitutional, the taxpayer argues that the tax statute is unconstitutional because it is applied retroactively. The taxpayer argues that the tax statute is retroactive because it applies to a taxpayer’s 2016 taxes, which were assessed and paid in 2017, and 2017 taxes, which were assessed and paid in 2018. See Md. Tax-Gen. Code Ann. § 13-103(a) (“Each taxpayer shall pay the taxes for the taxable year on or before the date prescribed by law.”) (emphasis added); see also Bancroft Information Group, Inc., supra, 91 Md.App. at 115, 603 A.2d at 1293 (<HOLDING>). 3. Retroactivity of Tax Statutes The Maryland Tax Court has held that tax statutes are not retroactive. See, e.g., Bancroft Information Group, Inc., supra, 91 Md.App. at 115, 603 A.2d at 1293 (<HOLDING>); see also CJP § 3-409(b) (“A taxpayer may not bring an action in a circuit court to determine the validity of a tax or to seek a declaratory judgment that a tax is erroneously, illegally, or wrongfully assessed or collected in any manner.”) (emphasis added); CJP § 3-409(b) (<HOLDING>). The Maryland Tax Court has held that taxpayers may only seek refunds of taxes that have been erroneously, illegally, or wrongfully assessed or collected in any manner. See, e.g., Bancroft Information Group, Inc., supra, 91 Md.App. at 115, 603 A.2d at 1293 (<HOLDING>); see also CJP § 3-409(b) (<HOLDING>). In addition, taxpayers may not seek a refund of taxes that have been assessed or collected in a manner that is “erroneous, illegal, or wrongful.” See, e.g., Bancroft Information Group, Inc., supra, 91 Md.App. at 115, 603 A.2d at 1293 (<HOLDING>); see also CJP § 3-409(b) (<HOLDING>). 4. The Maryland Tax Court’s Decision The Maryland Tax Court has held that taxpayers may not seek a refund of taxes that have been erroneously, illegally, or wrongfully assessed or collected in any manner. See, e.g., Bancroft Information Group, Inc., supra, 91 Md.App. at 115, 603 A.2d at 1293 (<HOLDING>); see also CJP § 3-409(b) (<HOLDING>). In addition, taxpayers may not seek a refund of taxes that have been assessed or collected in a manner that is “erroneous, illegal, or wrongful.” See, e.g., Bancroft Information Group, Inc., supra, 91 Md.App. at 115, 603 A.2d at 1293 (<HOLDING>); see also CJP § 3-409(b) (<HOLDING>). The Maryland Tax Court has held that taxpayers may not seek a refund of taxes that have been erroneously, illegally, or wrongfully assessed or collected in any manner. See, e.g., Bancroft Information Group, Inc., supra, 91 Md.App. at 115, 603 A.2d at 1293 (<HOLDING>); see also CJP § 3-409(b) (<HOLDING>). In addition, taxpayers may not seek a refund of taxes that have been assessed or collected in a manner that is “erroneous, illegal, or wrongful.” See, e.g., Bancroft Information Group, Inc., supra, 91 Md.App. at 115, 603 A.2d at 1293 (<HOLDING>); see also CJP § 3-409(b) (<HOLDING>). 5. prompt: Express, Inc., 334 Pa.Super. 295, 483 A.2d 456 (1984). Although such statements may ultimately prove to be false or maliciously motivated, the same may be said of statements made by a party who consults with his or her attorney preliminary to instituting a civil action, or of statements made by counsel in preliminary conferences or negotiations on their client’s behalf. Nevertheless, such statements are deemed to be absolutely privileged because the policy concerns stated above outweigh the right of the defamation plaintiff to seek redress for harm caused by the statements. Pawlowski v. Smorto, 403 Pa.Super. 71, 588 A.2d 36, 41-42 (1991) (footnote omitted) (emphasis added). See also Marino v. Fava, 915 A.2d 121, 124 (Pa.Super.2006), appeal denied, 592 Pa. 782, 926 A.2d 975 (2007) (<HOLDING>). Herein, Appellant admits Appellee’s allegedly
example: holding that statements an uncle made in an application to have his nephew involuntarily committed along with those he later made at the commitment hearing were absolutely privileged and could not form the basis for a defamation action
model:
defamatory statements were made by a party or his or her attorney preliminary to the institution of a civil action. See Pawlowski, 403 Pa.Super. at 42, 588 A.2d at 39 (“[W]e hold that the statements made by counsel in preliminary conferences or negotiations are absolutely privileged.”); see also Marino, 915 A.2d at 124 (“[T]he statements made by counsel in the course of preliminary conferences or negotiations are privileged.”).

Moreover, the court in Pawlowski held that the privilege applies even when the defamatory statements are made in the course of a settlement negotiation. Pawlowski, 403 Pa.Super. at 42, 588 A.2d at 39. See also Marino, 915 A.2d at 124 (<HOLDING>). Herein, Appellee allegedly made the statements in the course of settlement negotiations.

Appellant’s argument that the privilege should not apply because Appellee’s statements were made in the course of settlement negotiations, rather than in the course of preliminary conferences or negotiations, is unpersuasive. See Pawlowski, 403 Pa.Super. at 42, 588 A.2d at 39 (“The privilege applies regardless of whether the statements are made in the course of preliminary conferences or negotiations.”); Marino, 915 A.2d at 124 (<HOLDING>); see also S.P. v. S.P., 626 Pa. 234, 58 A.3d 1083, 1089 (2012) (<HOLDING>).

Finally, Appellant’s argument that the privilege should not apply because Appellee’s statements were not made in good faith is unpersuasive. See Pawlowski, 403 Pa.Super. at 42, 588 A.2d at 39 (“The privilege applies regardless of the good faith or bad faith of the party asserting it.”); see also Marino, 915 A.2d at 124 (<HOLDING>); S.P., 58 A.3d at 1089 (<HOLDING>).

Accordingly, we hold that the trial court properly granted summary judgment in favor of Appellee on Appellant’s defamation claim. See Pawlowski, 403 Pa.Super. at 42, 588 A.2d at 39; see also Marino, 915 A.2d at 124; S.P., 58 A.3d at 1089.

We also note that the trial court properly granted summary judgment in favor of Appellee on Appellant’s conspiracy claim. See Pawlowski, 403 Pa.Super. at 42, 588 A.2d at 39; see also Marino, 915 A.2d at 124; S.P., 58 A.3d at 1089.

Finally, we note that the trial court properly granted summary judgment in favor of Appellee on Appellant’s fraud claim. See Pawlowski, 403 Pa.Super. at 42, 588 A.2d at 39; see also Marino, 915 A.2d at 124; S.P., 58 A.3d at 1089.

Accordingly, we affirm the trial court’s order granting summary judgment in favor of Appellee on all of Appellant’s claims. See Pawlowski, 403 Pa.Super. at 42, 588 A.2d at 39; see also Marino, 915 A.2d at 124; S.P., 58 A.3d at 1089.

AND NOW, this 26th day of August, 2013, the order of the trial court is AFFIRMED.

Judgment Entered.

model:
We first consider whether and to what extent the Debtors have an interest in the SARs under Kansas law. The Debtors argue that they have an interest in the SARs under Kansas law, and that this interest is property of the estate under § 541(a)(1). The Trustee argues that the Debtors’ interest in the SARs is a mere expectancy, and therefore not a property interest under Kansas law. The Trustee also argues that the Debtors’ interest in the SARs is not an interest in property under § 541(a)(1).

The Debtors have not provided any Kansas cases or statutes that support their argument that they have an interest in the SARs under Kansas law. The Debtors have cited only two Kansas cases in support of their argument. See In re Higbee, 300 B.R. 850, 853-54 (Bankr.D.Kan.2003) (<HOLDING>); In re Higbee, 299 B.R. 719, 722-23 (Bankr.D.Kan.2003)
(<HOLDING>). But these cases do not provide any support for
the Debtors’ position.

In Higbee, the bankruptcy court held that the debtor had an interest in the SARs under Kansas law. See 300 B.R. at 853-54. But the court did not hold that the debtor’s interest in the SARs was a property interest under § 541(a)(1). Id. at 854. Instead, the court held that the debtor’s interest in the SARs was a mere expectancy, and therefore not a property interest under § 541(a)(1). Id. at 854-55.

In Higbee, the debtor was a stockbroker who had sold the SARs to a customer. See 300 B.R. at 852. The debtor had no right to receive the SARs until the customer exercised the SARs. See id. The bankruptcy court held that the debtor’s interest in the SARs was a mere expectancy, and therefore not a property interest under § 541(a)(1). Id. at 854-55. The court noted that the debtor had no right to receive the SARs until the customer exercised them. See id. at 855. The court also noted that the debtor’s interest in the SARs was not a property interest because the debtor had no right to receive the SARs until the customer exercised them. See id.

The Trustee argues that the Debtors’ interest in the SARs is a mere expectancy, and therefore not a property interest under § 541(a)(1). The Trustee points to the fact that the Debtors have no right to receive the SARs until the customer exercises them. See In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 722 (<HOLDING>). The Trustee also points out that the Debtors’ interest in the SARs is not a property interest because the Debtors have no right to receive the SARs until the customer exercises them. See id.

We agree with the Trustee that the Debtors’ interest in the SARs is a mere expectancy, and therefore not a property interest under § 541(a)(1). See In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 722 (<HOLDING>); see also In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>); In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 722 (<HOLDING>).

We also agree with the Trustee that the Debtors’ interest in the SARs is not an interest in property under § 541(a)(1). See 11 U.S.C. § 541(a)(1); In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 722-23 (<HOLDING>); see also In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>).

We conclude that the Debtors’ interest in the SARs is a mere expectancy, and therefore not a property interest under § 541(a)(1). See In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 722-23 (<HOLDING>); see also In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>). Accordingly, the Debtors’ interest in the SARs is not an interest in property under § 541(a)(1). See 11 U.S.C. § 541(a)(1); In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 722-23 (<HOLDING>); see also In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>).

We note that the Trustee also argues that the Debtors’ interest in the SARs is not a property interest under § 541(a)(1) because the SARs are not “securities” within the meaning of § 541(a)(1). See 11 U.S.C. § 541(a)(1); see also In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 723 (<HOLDING>); In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>). But this argument is not relevant to our decision. See In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 723 (<HOLDING>); see also In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>).

Accordingly, we hold that the Debtors’ interest in the SARs is not an interest in property under § 541(a)(1). See 11 U.S.C. § 541(a)(1); In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 722-23 (<HOLDING>); see also In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>).

We conclude that the Debtors’ interest in the SARs is not a property interest under § 541(a)(1), and therefore the SARs are not property of the estate under § 541(a)(1). See 11 U.S.C. § 541(a)(1); In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 722-23 (<HOLDING>); see also In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>).

We note that the Trustee also argues that the Debtors’ interest in the SARs is not an interest in property under § 541(a)(1) because the SARs are not “securities” within the meaning of § 541(a)(1). See 11 U.S.C. § 541(a)(1); see also In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 723 (<HOLDING>); In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>). But this argument is not relevant to our decision. See In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 723 (<HOLDING>); see also In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>).

We conclude that the Debtors’ interest in the SARs is not an interest in property under § 541(a)(1). See 11 U.S.C. § 541(a)(1); In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 722-23 (<HOLDING>); see also In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>). Accordingly, the SARs are not property of the estate under § 541(a)(1). See 11 U.S.C. § 541(a)(1); In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 722-23 (<HOLDING>); see also In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>).

We note that the Trustee also argues that the Debtors’ interest in the SARs is not an interest in property under § 541(a)(1) because the SARs are not “securities” within the meaning of § 541(a)(1). See 11 U.S.C. § 541(a)(1); see also In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 723 (<HOLDING>); In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>). But this argument is not relevant to our decision. See In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 723 (<HOLDING>); see also In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>).

Accordingly, we affirm the bankruptcy court’s order holding that the SARs are not property of the estate under § 541(a)(1). See 11 U.S.C. § 541(a)(1); In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 722-23 (<HOLDING>); see also In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>).

We note that the Trustee also argues that the Debtors’ interest in the SARs is not an interest in property under § 541(a)(1) because the SARs are not “securities” within the meaning of § 541(a)(1). See 11 U.S.C. § 541(a)(1); see also In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 723 (<HOLDING>); In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>). But this argument is not relevant to our decision. See In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 723 (<HOLDING>); see also In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>).

We conclude that the Debtors’ interest in the SARs is not an interest in property under § 541(a)(1), and therefore the SARs are not property of the estate under § 541(a)(1). See 11 U.S.C. § 541(a)(1); In re Higbee, 299 B.R. at 722-23 (<HOLDING>); see also In re Cox, 2009 WL 3890058, at *11 (Bankr.D.Kan. Nov. 16, 2009) (<HOLDING>). example: The winner of this case is Koons Buick Pontiac GMC, Inc..
model: In this case, Bradley Nigh sued Koons Buick Pontiac GMC under the federal Truth in Lending Act (TILA) for intentionally charging him for a car feature for which he did not agree to pay. The federal district court awarded Nigh approximately $24,000 in damages. Koons Buick appealed and argued that the district court ignored the $1,000 cap on damages set forth in TILA. The Fourth Circuit held that a 1995 amendment to TILA removed the $1,000 cap on recoveries involving loans secured by personal property, such as a car. Therefore, the court affirmed the district court's award of damages to Nigh."
